region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious, healthy, inexpensive and easy to modify! I've made this recipe about 4 times so far. I dump everything (the beans, and vegetables) into a blender and blend it all together. I then dump it all into a kitchen towel (flour sack towels) and squeeze all the liquid out over the sink. This gets rid of all the excess liquid and the patties stay together quite nicely. If you make smaller patties, then this recipe yields a lot. I have started cutting squares of wax paper, brushing oil on them and then stacking the patties with the wax paper in between. I then freeze them. When I'm hungry, I pull a few out of the freezer and heat them in the oven for a quick and delicious meal.

text:
This is a great recipe! Be sure to let the beans dry a bit (I let them sit in the strainer). I use red peppers, corn, grated (and then minced) carrots, minced onions, and/or whatever I have on hand. Instead of hot sauce and chili powder, I use berbere (an Ethiopian spice), for a milder but more complex taste. For the bread crumbs, I usually use some mixture of crumbled stale bread and crushed whole wheat saltines. Once these did not hold together at all on the pan, so I roughly chopped up the patty with my spatula and fried it with rice, and served it with sliced avocado for an amazing and quick variation.

I just made these and I have to say they were delicious! I followed other reviewers suggestions and rinsed and drained the beans before I mashed them. I also strained the onion/garlic/pepper mixture after I chopped it in the processor. The only change I made was that I used 1 cup of bread crumbs instead of 1/2. They came out really good and really good, but could use some tweaking. The next time I make them I plan to do the following: add 1 more egg, cook them 1-2 minutes longer on each side, use less cumin and add cilantro. I think with those additions they will be the perfect black bean burgers. Overall a great recipe, but room for improvement!

text:
Great recipe! I only modified the preparation, so this definitely deserves the five stars.  I followed other reviewers advice about running the green pepper, onion, and garlic through the food processor, adding the egg/spice mixture to that, then running the beans through the food processor. This resulted in perfect patties that didn't fall apart.  I put them on oiled foil and placed the foil in a hot cast iron griddle. I don't think these would have the same appealing texture if they were baked, so grill them if you can!

I was looking for a healthy meat-alternative burger and stumbled across this one.  I took the advice of America's Test Kitchen and used 2 egg yolks instead of 1 whole egg to get them to stick together better which really helped with assembly and cooking.  I also added Worcestershire sauce and 5 cloves of garlic instead of 3 and they were amazing.  I've made them four times now, and even made them for a vegetarian friend and she said they were the best thing she'd tasted in months and months (granted she does have 3 kids and rarely gets a moment to eat, but I still took it as a compliment!).  Serve them up with avocado, tomato, and other fresh fixins and you won't miss the meat at all, promise.

city:

country:

text:
Edit: Here is another tip that I picked up for those with lose or unevenly cooked patties. For uniform patties, spoon and flatten the mixture into a mold. I like to use a large cookie cutter(for sliders), but you can remove both sides of a tuna can and have perfect patties every time while avoiding messy hands! This way you can even make them onto wax paper squares and freeze for later.
Veggies such as onions and peppers contain excess water that must be squeezed out. If this still fails then add enough bread crumbs to get that ground meat texture.

I've made this twice within the same week. Actions like that speak louder than any review that I could possibly give! I'm allergic to half of the store-bought varieties out there which had some ingredients worthy of a google search. It was refreshing to not only have a do it yourself recipe but this was simple, fast, healthy for myself and my budget.  I found that topping the buns with some of the thai chili sauce and ketchup(the organic version at my grocer actually costs less than the regular one) was a perfect sauce for the burger. The closest thing that I could come to describing it as would be a spicy cousin to the Polynesian sauce at Chik-fil-a. Besides it's always great to pair the sauce with a major ingredient, right? Crisp romaine or a slice of tomato really take the edge off of the chili sauce. I prefer mine baked and if I'm not using the pepperidge farm thin buns, then these make great sliders or enchilada fillers.

text:
Was surprised that I liked these. Was hesitant about making them because I have never used black beans before. Rinsed and dried the black beans. In the food processor I pulsed the green pepper, onion, garlic, and a handful of carrots, then put the mixture in a strainer and was surprised at how much liquid I squeezed out, very important to do so the patties stay formed. Put the black beans in the processor and pulsed to a nice consistency. Mixed veggie mixture and beans together in a bowl adding the egg, chili powder, cumin, hot sauce and bread crumbs. I did add a little extra bread crumbs. Formed into patties, put on parchment paper on a cookie sheet and put in freezer. When frozen I put the ones I would not be cooking in a freezer baggie for another healthy, quick meal. Served on a 1 point wheat roll with lettuce, tomato and mayo for a total of 5 points on Weight Watchers. (the patty is 3 points) So glad I tried these. Will always have some of these made in my freezer.
Review:

5

text:
Homemade Black Bean Veggie Burger Haiku: "The most helpful tip? Freeze a bit before grilling. (Or they'll fall apart.) VERY filling and delicious, either served on a pita w/ chipotle mayo, avocado and tomato slices, or dressed up like a regular burger w/ traditional trimmings. I've made them w/ crushed Triscuit crackers in place of bread crumbs, and 1/2 tsp. Siriacha, which gives the perfect kick! I wrap the 4 patties in plastic and freeze them for 1-2 days prior to grilling (or baking), and then grill them in a well-oiled pouch of foil, or in a skillet coated w/ cooking spray. Never buying packaged BB patties again!

None
text:
Really tasty... follow this suggestion for keeping it together:   I love these burgers. Let me tell you how to keep them from falling apart, though. First, you must rinse the black beans and dry them off before mashing them. Second, you must strain the onion, garlic and pepper mixture through a fine strainer to remove any excess water. Third, if you add 50% more bread crumbs, it will hold much better. Also, I freeze mine and grill them frozen. Doing this has keep my burgers intact and my mouth happy! Also, I always follow the spice/hot sauce measurments pretty well, and I do not find it too spicy at all, and I find black pepper to be spicy! Hope this helps with the loose burger issue.

text:
I was happy that these burgers held up well for me. I read the reviews and removed as much liquid from the equation as possible. I set the onion and pepper on a kitchen towel and drained as twisted out as much moisture as I could. I also dried the beans after draining and rinsing them. The burgers shaped beautifully and we grilled them without mishap. They looked beautiful. I like the recipe and will use it again. Unfortunately I had to take it down a star, because my husband still wasn't too fond of the consistency. He said, "It tastes like refried beans of a bun." He wasn't necessarily saying that's a bad thing, but it wasn't totally complimentary, either. Anyway, the recipe is definitely a great starting point which can be altered based on your personal preferences.

text:
These were awesome!  I don't know what everyone is talking about, you DO NOT need to add an extra egg!  The burgers would been disgusting goo with 2 eggs!  I followed the recipe exactly except I forgot to pick up a bell pepper at the store.  I used a couple of tablespoons of chopped jalapenos (from a jar, NOT fresh) instead and it gave the burgers a little heat that my husband loved.  I will say I did use paper towels to try to remove as much excess water as possible from the beans and jalapenos before I added them to the mix.  I also just threw all the ingredients into the food processor and mixed it together all at once.  After I cooked the burgers in the oven they looked and tasted like regular hamburgers.  Very similar in consistency to ground beef.  My husband is a big time carnivore and he literally could not believe the burgers didn't have any meat in them!  We both thought they were awesome!

text:
These are great!  I stopped eating store bought veggie burgers since they all seem to have soy, corn or wheat in them--and I'm allergic to all 3.  I've made these at least half a dozen times now. The first time I made these I followed the recipe exactly and the taste of the cumin was a little too strong for me and they were a little wet and messy.  I've adjusted each time I make them and don't really measure the ingredients anymore.  I add enough bread crumbs (gluten free) to get the texture I want and usually end up using more bell pepper and onion than the amount listed.  I adjust the seasoning to my taste and add salt and pepper.  Sometimes I also add some shredded cheese.  I always bake them using a parchment lined cookie sheet sprayed with cooking spray.  Fantastic!

These were pretty good.  My daughter who doesn't eat a lot of meat really enjoyed them.  She had a homemade veggie burger at a local restaurant that had wheat germ in it so I wanted to incorporate some for extra nutrients.  I doubled the recipe, used hot chile paste instead of chili sauce, used 1/2 cup bread crumbs and 1/2 cup wheat germ.  I didn't have any lettuce or tomato on hand, but those would have been excellent toppings, and also some avocado would have been tasty as others have suggested.  I baked at 375 for about 25 minutes to get them a little crunchy on the outside, but they were still moist inside.  I would definitely make these again.

I scaled the recipe up to 6 and this yielded 10 good size patties. I scaled the spices down and omited the chili sauce to accomodate those who didn't want spicy, and instead served these with a homemade spicy chipotle ranch burger sauce on the side. text:
I am a relatively recent vegetarian and was very hungry come lunch time. So on a whim I figured I'd try making a black bean burger instead of a Boca burger. This recipe is freaking amazing. I did make some minor modifications (which mirrored some of the ones in other reviews). I get a little freaked when I have to use lots of hot spices and such, so I cut the Cumin down to 1 tsp. and used 1 cup of bread. I only formed one patty and baked it at the temp. the recipe called for. Though in the last minute or so before I pulled it out to eat I put a piece of cheese on top and let it melt over it. So delicious! I formed and wrapped up 3 other patties for the freezer and can't wait to make them and share them with my friends and family. Great recipe!!! :]

text:
Delicious! The whole family loved these. I took some of the tips from the reviews and added more bread crumbs than called for. I actually put the beans in the food processor - much easier! Then I processed the onion and garlic, and drained it before adding to the beans. I also made the patties (8 for a double recipe) thinner, and froze them prior to cooking. This made them hold together as the mixture was quite soft. I pan fried them frozen, about 10 minutes on each side. I served them with all the condiments I would normally use on hamburgers, and  they were very tasty. Thank you!!

text:
The veggie burgers in the store are bland and pasty.  This one is superb in every way!  I left out the hot sauce and cut the chili powder in 1/3 (I'm hypersensitive to spicy foods) and it tasted spiced and passive.  I chopped the veggies in a small cuisinart.  I decided to put everything in the cuisinart. The end result was smooth and tasty.  I'd like some small bits of unique flavors, so I'll leave out a bit of the chopped veggies and incorporate it after I cuisinart everything else. I drained and dried the ingredients as best I could and the mix was still too wet.  I added more bread crumbs per other suggestions.  Good idea.  I also added carrots and spinach.  The recipe portions are too big for me.  I made a double batch and baked 1/2 to store, freeze and nuke.   This also makes a great spread raw.  I'll definitely make this again and again.

We've made these three times now and they are a hit.  The first time, I tried to fry them and they just fell apart.  2nd and 3rd time, I've baked them. text:
YUM! I made this *for the second time* last night. I have to be  honest and say the first time around it didn't work out too well. I dont own a food processor so I chopped the onions and what not but not finely enough.. secondly I didn't heed the other reviewers recommendation on using two eggs. They came out dry and chunky (not in a good way).  But last night I decided to re do this recipe at friend's house. I still chopped the onions and peppers (finely this time). Instead of bell peppers I used 2 seeded jalapenos. I used two eggs instead of one. I ended up needing half of another can of black beans. I also added a tea spoon of cayenne pepper. Once I had them ready to go in the oven I cracked some black pepper on the top- and the same when I flipped them. I served them actually on a piece of toast (open face) with a champagne garlic mustard and three slices of avocado... let's just say I found myself writing out the recipe several times last night for several friends.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I love the flavor of these.  I tried two different ways of to make them, to see which way I would like best.  The first batch I tried following the recipe directions exactly, and I ended up with pureed green pepper and onions,(with a few huge chunks still left in it).  I knew it would be way too much liquid from this puree, so I drained this well and proceeded with the recipe.  These patties stayed together very well, and tasted good.  The second batch I just finely diced the green pepper and onion, and then followed the recipe.  These patties were very dry and would not hold together, but the flavor was amazing.  So I guess the verdict is, if I want patties that stick together I will follow the directions and just add a 'drain the vegetables' step in there.  This recipe is definitely a keeper for me.

text:
Wow! I made these for my Memorial Day barbeque last weekend and they were a hug hit! Some of the guys actually stopped eating the meat and switched to these! I did find them a little soft to work with, but took another reviewer's suggestion and cooked them frozen. I cooked them on the grill on a piece of foil, which worked well and then baked one in the oven for lunch on Tuesday. Yum yum! One suggestion: make sure to use a non-stick spray if grilling or baking. Otherwise they stick and come apart when you try to flip them.  Thanks for sharing a great recipe!

text:
This was DELICIOUS!!!  I only used 1/4 of an onion, though, and instead of going through a food processor I just chopped everything pretty small.  I also made my own bread crumbs from toasted bread.  That helped cut down on the calories (I used that 45 calorie Sarah Lee bread).  I also used Egg Beaters instead of an egg, and used skim milk.  I used Bush's Black Beans with reduced sodium also.  This cut my calories down to around 120 per burger!!  I'm playing with the idea of vegetarianism just for health's sake, and this recipe is really making that transition a smooth one!  I think I preferred it over meat burgers!!  Thanks for this recipe!!!

text:
Absolutely Incredible!  I love my meat... but lets face it, black beans are cheaper and healthier!  I doubled this recipie and made a few changes. I took pevious reviewers advice and squeezed the excess water out of my Red Bell Peppers. Changes:I added 1 tsp of Onion Powder (instead of fresh onions), about 1/2 cup of powdered parmesan cheese, and 1/2 cup of drained canned corn.  Even though the doubled recipe called for two eggs, I only put one in - two eggs would have made the bean mash too runny.    I will definetly be making this one again.  Lots of flavor and great texture!  I didn't miss my 1/2 lb beef burger at all!

text:
I expected this recipe to be good, but I'm blown away with how tasty this turned out.  I'm not even vegetarian and I would take these over a beef burger any day.  I doubled the recipe, the only thing I changed was adding -bit- more bread crumbs than called for.  For a doubled recipe I probably added less than a quarter cup extra.  I used the same proportion of spices it called for and didn't find it tasted of cumin too much at all, as some reviewers have complained.  I did grind the veggies to almost a paste before adding them to the bean mixture, and the hot sauce I used was Sriracha chili sauce, which I feel made all the difference.  Topped with simple american cheese, lettuce, tomato, pickle, ketchup and mustard, this was easily the best homemade burger I've ever had.  I will -definitely- make this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these so many times that I know the recipe by heart.  First of all, I do substitute 1/2 cup oats for the bread crumbs.  I don't add more than what is called for.  When you mix everything together, it does seem more 'watery' than typical hamburger -- but it's supposed to be.  If you add more bread crumbs (or oats) they'll end up dry and bland.  I ONLY bake these in the oven on a parchment lined cookie sheet.  On the grill or BBQ they'd just be a complete mess.  Also, play around with the seasonings to make it your own.  Sometimes I don't add cumin and hot sauce but add 1 TBSP of Worchestershire sauce and diced Swiss along with the other ingredients.  Enjoy!

WOW! I am just starting to cook vegetarian cuisine (Its my new years resolution!) and this is wonderful, even my meat eating husband ate two! When making the patties I used about 3/4 cup bread crumbs and substituted green taco sauce and 1/4 red and 1/4 green peppers. I also cooked these quite a bit longer than called for, about 17 minutes on each side. I served these on toasted whole wheat buns with organic cheese, lettuce and tomato, but what *really* made it awesome was reviewer Jamie Ks suggestion of chipotle mayo, the patties themselves are a little bland, but coupled with the mayo these were delicious!

text:
This recipe is awesome!! Have made it several times now, and it is a hit. Make sure to drain off the liquid from the veggies before adding. I've also noticed for some reason different brands of beans are wetter than others. If your mixture seems too soft, pop it in the fridge for a while before making your patties. It'll hold together better.  These also make the best taco filling ever!!

These were incredibly good. My boyfriend is a vegetarian and we have had store bought black bean burgers, but these were by far better.  I used purple onion and cheese seasoned bread crumbs because that is what I had.  I just added the crumbs until it was a good molding consistency.  I also added brown rice which gave them a great chewy texture.  These were fine placing directly on the grill and the cooked texture was was fabulous.  My boyfriend was so very impressed and can't wait to make them again.  I also loved that I made them large enough to go on the big wheat buns.

text:
This was a very delicious recipe that was much better than I expected due to my previous  encounters with veggie burgers. I had to make a few changes due to lack of ingredients and advice from other reviews. To prevent the burger from being too wet, I dried the beans after rinsing as well as squeezed the liquid out of the veggie mix.  I was low on breadcrumbs, so  I threw in 1/3 cup brown rice in addition to the 1/3 cup bread crumbs I had into the food processor.  I also substituted cayenne pepper for the hot sauce.  Overall this turned out excellent and the patties stayed together in the oven.  I would highly recommend this to anyone!

text:
I thought these were Delicious!!  I used tabasco instead of thai chili sauce, and i mashed the beans with a pastry cutter because a fork wasn't working well and it started to hurt my hand. I ommited the onion because we had none, used a red pepper instead of green.  I also put the red pepper in the blender, because i don't own a food processor, and put the garlic cloves through a garlic press. I didn't really measure out the bread crumbs but rather, tore up pieces of multi-grain bread until the bean mixture began sticking to itself (probably required about 4 slices).  I grilled it on a charcoal grill on tin foil and froze the rest and it turned out great.  I just put one of the frozen ones on the foreman grill for lunch and it tasted just as delicious as the first one I made.  Definitly will make these again.

text:
MMmmmmmm~ tasty. I followed the advice of others and made some minor changes to the recipe... Used garlic powder instead of garlic (none on hand), halved the cumin and chili powder, and substituted a can of mushrooms (drained) for the green peppers. The final change I made was to use rolled oats that were pulverized in my chopper to mimick breadcrumbs. I added as much rolled oats to the mix that it could tolerate... my hands were sore from the mixing! Slapped the babies on the fry pan and it came out perfectly. Didn't fall apart at all~ This will definitely make it into our regular rotation in the future.

I used 2 eggs and 1 cup bread crumbs. I was a little unsure about the seasoning, since some reviewers said it was bland, and others didn't like the cumin. I substituted 1 TB of a GrillMates powdered marinade from an envelope packet (used 'Southwest' flavor, but any would be good). Skipped the cumin/chili/hot sauce. Delish! Will try this again with different veggies - black olives, shredded carrot, etc. to keep it interesting. Freezes well. Served with lettuce, tomato, and a slice of American on a toasted whole wheat bun.

text:
These were amazing!  I just chopped the onion, pepper and garlic really fine, mashed the beans with a potato masher (they were not cooperating with the fork...), used chipotle flavored tabasco and I halved the chili powder and cumin, thinking I wasn't really into those flavors.  Next time I will use the full amount, as the beans really need that flavor - they seem to absorb it.  I baked them and they were awesome - since I had the chipotle flavors going, I squeezed a little lime juice over the patties before serving.   Used a little less than 1/2 cup of bread crumbs and had no problems with patties falling apart.  Great recipe!

text:
These are awesome! I can't believe they turned out so good because I accidently added way too much bread crumbs. But after baking them, freezing them, and then reheating them, the strong bread crumb taste it had when I first ate it right after it came out of the oven disappeared. Next time I'm trying them with less bread crums and instead of baking them, I'll just freeze them and then cook them in the pan. Since I didn't have green bell pepper, I just used one whole onion and it was awesome that way, but I really like onion. I also thought that the 1 tablespoon of chilli powder would be too much but I'm so glad I decided to add it anyway, it gave a great taste.

text:
I just finished cleaning up dinner and these black bean burgers were a hit! I doubled the recipe in fear of not having enough burgers for everyone, but it made as much as it said. I got 8 really heaping burgers out of the mix, and they are big! I ended up putting more like 1 1/2 cups of bread crumbs, and I also used my electric chopper to chop (or mush) all of the ingredients. Also I only used one teaspoon of chili powder, and one teaspoon of cumin. My eaters don't really like spicy, and this amount was perfect! The spices gave it taste, but there was no extra kick. I give the recipe the 4 instead of a 5 because it was really wet, and I ended up cooking them for 20 mins in the oven, then I put them in a frying man to finish them off. I finished the plate off with a whole wheat multi grain bun, sautéed onions, french-fries and steamed broccoli with corn. Make these! They are great!

text:
Delicious!!! My first veggie burger ever and it was GREAT! I followed the recipe exactly except for adding an extra egg since I didnt' want to deal with a mixture that doesn't stick together and used a 1 cup measuring cup (sprayed with cooking spray) to help shape my patties to perfection! I got 5 wonderful, thick patties from the recipe and I baked  them in the oven. I had to bake them a bit longer than the time called for so I broiled each side on high for an extra 3-5 minutes at the very end, but that wasn't a problem because it was common sense to do so since the patties were still too soft after 10 minutes on each side. We ate it on hamburger buns with lettuce, some Miracle Whip, and lots of ketchup (you need lots of ketchup when eating these because for some reason it tastes way better that way)! Thanks for sharing this recipe! I'll be making these over and over again!

text:
I made this tonight along with the Apricot Glazed Carrots for a side dish for dinner.  My 3 yr old loved both dishes.  MAde it with cheese melted on it.  I made a few on the non stick skillet and a few on my george foreman.  I prefer the browning and crispier taste on the skillet.  Can't wait to try it on a real bbq when it's warmer.  It made a lot more for me than 4 patties (made them to fit those regular hamburger buns).  I also did 2 more garlic cloves than recipe stated.  In addition to the veggies stated, I finally chopped some broccoli heads, celery.  Loved the texture and crunch.  Spices were nice.. but I might change it up as I go on.  Will use this recipe again and yes... very inexpensive way to make these burgers (hint.. stock up when beans go on sale!).  Thanks for the recipe.  **Update** 10/12/09  Using dried beans now.  I presoak a bag, partially cook them and freeze them into 16oz or so bags.  Just take out what I need and run them under hot water and follow the recipe.  I've tweaked it as I went along, adding some onion and garlic powder, along with some mrs. dash.  Otherwise very good and simple recipe.  Dried beans is the way to go, longer process but a bag can make up to 4 meals with it.

I've made this recipe several times now and it's always a hit.  I now form the patties and put them in the fridge for half an hour --it has reduced how much they fall apart on the grill, though I find that a pan on the barbecue is a good place to start them.  When they're firm enough, move them to the grill for a final sizzle on the 'cue.

text:
These were GOOD - really really GOOD!  I didn't have any hot sauce or cumin, but otherwise followed the recipe.  Although I made thise recipe for my vegetarian daughter, my husband and I both tried it and enjoyed.  I made the burgers too big (only 3), forgetting they don't shrink like our beef burgers. We had a little trouble flipping it, so used a second sheet of foil and just put it on top and then flipped, pulling off the old foil.  It worked perfectly.   We froze the left overs, hoping they will be just as good next time we pull out burgers for dinner. EDIT:  The burgers we froze turned out to be just as delicious.  Freeze them on a tray and thaw individually on the foil you intend to cook them on.

text:
This is a standard dish in my household now.  Several years ago, I switched to a pescatarian diet, and this is something I make fairly frequently.

If you want a twist on this recipe, substitute different spices for the cumin, chili powder and chili sauce.  I did an Asian variation with ginger, sesame seeds and katsu sauce that turned out splendidly!

A food processor is ideal for chopping, but I've also been able to hand-chop it for more of a textured burger.  It's less smooth, but more natural-style to me.

I cannot recommend this recipe enough!

userID:
21599584
Display Name:
Acadia Branch
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe and have made it many times now. I'm an incredibly amatuer cook and this is one of things I make when I'm trying to impress someone. 

For all you other amateurs, here's what I learned to do this best:  
- I mash the black beans, a half can or less at a time, with the back a big spoon. This took me way too long to figure out. 
- I absolutely have to strain the pepper and onion to remove excess water. It keeps the burgers together. HOWEVER I don't own a fine strainer, or have cheesecloth, so after much finagling I finally found a solution. Whatever cloth-- clean cotton dish towel, unused embroidery fabric, old tshirt-- becomes my cheese cloth. It works well! but heads up it will stain your fabric slightly green. 
- Because I strained everything, I don't need as much breadcrumbs which really contributes to flavor. 
- I double the recipe. It takes long enough to make (like an 1hr 30min for my slow self) that it's worth making only once and having leftovers. The burgers freeze really well, just put something in between them. 
- Also, in general, I get more and more liberal with the spices each time I make this. The black beans are forgiving. 

I love this recipe and it gives me a lot of *cooking confidence* that I can do it well now. Enjoy!

text:
A few changes, along with the highest rated suggestions of draining veggies and beans, and adding breadcrumbs:

I use a whole bag of dried beans, quadruple the veggies, and add two eggs instead of one. Season to taste. I've started freezing the leftover juice from the peppers, onions, and garlic and adding it to my pressure cooker with a bag of dried black beans and whatever seasonings I feel like using to get some of the nutrients back in there and give it a more flavorful base in my next batch.

It works great as a large batch - it's enough for a week or two of filling, individual meals. Usually keep it in the fridge and cook it a serving at a time, but I'll freeze it first if I'm planning on a more varied week.

Trying it with fresh ginger, cumin seeds, turmeric, fresh ground coriander, and fresh ground cloves today. Can't wait, it smells super aromatic so far!

text:
These are delicious. I made a mixture of Anaheim, Jalapeno,   red, green, and yellow peppers, cilantro, leeks, and garlic; all roasted and placed in a blender. This added a wonderful flavor to the batch. I also cooked my black beans in a Crock-pot with salt, leeks, and red onions. 
For the egg mixture, I added cumin, kosher salt, smoked chili flakes and chili powder. I stirred in a Mexican blended cheese and Panko bread crumbs. I cooked the batch in the oven but I also have leftover mixture which I will try on the grill. 
Nothing falls apart if you adjust the amount of eggs (I used two) and amount of bread crumbs. My mixture was pretty thick. I used a little avocado oil on top just for moisture.  The flavors are so yummy!

text:
Do not make this as written!      Watery and tastes medicinal!  With a few changes in technique and one big change in contents you will have success.     

•To deal with the watery:   Strain and rinse beans and let them dry on a cookie sheet for an hour.   Strain and blot dry the onion/garlicc/pepper mixture  AFTER you chop it fine.  This will remove a lot of excess mosture.... the key is relative dryness when the egg is added. 

• To deal with the medicinal  forget about adding a whopping tablespoon Of cumin!    Try  a teaspoon.... 

Do these things and follow the rest of the recipe  as written and you will have a good base from which to explore different additions to suit your fancy.

I like adding the juice of 1/2  lime. (Which requires an additional tbs. of bread crumbs).  I also like adding kernel corn.   Read the other reviews they are full of great ideas and additions.  I got a lot of inspiration from others.   I think the lime juice is my contribution.... for what it's worth.

I'm not sure how anyone pulled this off as the recipe is written. I doubled the recipe to get 8 burgers. Besides using the ingredients in the recipe, I added fresh ground ginger. I needed 4 cups, yes 4 cups of Panko to get the mixture to firm up. I put the recipe into my "patty-staker" which turned in a disaster. (I missed the tip in the reviews to use olive oil on your hands to handle the patty making. After all this..they turned out AWESOME.. Reviews from people I gave them to, were rave reviews.

text:
This was a great jumping off point into the world of veggie burgers. I found that roasting a variety of veggies ( carrots, parsnips, onion, garlic, red peppers lightly oil seasoning salt and pepper ) in addition to the black beans was a great flavour adder. I pulsed the roasted veg in the food processor then added to the smashed black beans. Corn was also a nice last minute addition that I roasted. I even dried the beans in the oven to be hyper conscious of removing as much water from the ingredients to ensure they didn't fall apart at the end.  The seasoning needed some additions as well, but to each their own on the spices, I loved the Thai chili flavour in this recipe but added some dry spices like garlic powder, oregano, ground pepper, soya sauce, basil, dry mustard, garam masala or curry powder )Great addition in the comments about shaping and freezing the burgers btwn parchment in a container- it made the fairly time consuming task 100% worth it and helped in the cooking process. It was easier to skip the BBQ and do a light pan roast when they weren't frozen. I fed them to my veg friends who loved them! Plus my partner couldn't get enough of them- he tends to like a steak over a veggie burger any day! Happy cooking!

text:
I am a self proclaimed recipe "tweaker" so I tend to read recipes and get the overall concept and then just go with it...however, i have been transitioning my family to vegetarian/vegan meals and this is new so I don't have the confidence quite yet to tweak!  With that being said, I LOVED this recipe almost exactly as it was written.

Since I tend to not read the directions, I accidentally threw the beans into the food processor.  This actually worked out great.  In the processor went the beans, garlic and peppers (yellow and red since I did not have green). After I read the instructions again and realized I had placed the beans  in the food processor I scooped everything into a bowl.  I added the eggs and spices to the food processor bowl after taking the bean mixture out.  I used sriracha for hot sauce.  Once it was well blended I put it in with the beans.  Oatmeal was subbed for breadcrumbs (avoiding gluten) and I actually threw that into the food processor bowl and it cleaned up the egg/spices mixture.  I doubled the amount of oatmeal and the burgers were not runny and set up nicely!  Once everything was mixed I scooped out 1/2 cup portions and they kept the cup form nicely, I simply smoothed them out with a rubber spatula into burgers

I cooked in the oven for 10 minutes per side.  I did this early in the day and when it was time for dinner, I crisped them up in a pan with a small amount of olive oil.  My family (3.5, 16 and a manly man middle aged husband) LOVED them!

Very good base, but you can add a bit more "punch" to it. Here's how: Put half bread crumbs, and half crushed Doritos Sweet Chili Heat (Plus these chips are vegan!).I also add fresh mushrooms and spinach to the bean mixture. It really brings the flavours of the burger all together. 

Also, to get a better texture, try breading it, lightly, with panko. 

The Doritos and panko mix makes these burgers cripsy, and delicious.

text:
I'm a long time cook (40 yrs.) and cook  everything and made my own of this delicious recipe.  I used the basic recipe but added 1/2  cup of corn, three eggs and reversed the chili powder and cumin measurements. I added 2 teaspoons of sea salt, a load of fresh ground black pepper and hot sauce in addition to oats instead of bread crumbs. Instead of having problems some of the others did with a wet  mixture, I lined a cast iron skillet with parchment paper (all the way up the sides of the skillet) and baked at 375. This will be my burger for the summer. All I can say about this is awesome! I hate store bought veggie burgers and just can't get them down. But these are a different story altogether. After baking, I sliced and served with a big slab of tomato, purple onion and avocado. This doesn't need a bun in my opinion.  For those that aren't total vegans, a couple of slices of bacon would be excellent on these burgers.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time I made it I'd rate it a 3. I prepared it with ingredients as written except I used crushed Ritz crackers instead of breadcrumbs because that's what I had on hand. I mashed the beans by using my Bosch mixer with wire whips and continued using the mixer to stir in all other ingredients. As others suggested, I drained extra water from the chopped onion/pepper by pressing it in a fine sieve before adding it to the beans. Final consistency was like a thick paste so per suggestion of a reviewer I froze the patties before baking in the oven so they would hold up better. Baked flavor was bland, the patty was small, and the center felt mushy while the outside was too dry. Maybe that was a result of freezing? I just made the recipe for the second time and followed the same procedure as before plus the following changes: I doubled the recipe and made 5 patties total so each patty was more substantial, I added a little corn, I squeezed the chopped onion/pepper/corn in cheesecloth and extracted WAY more water than before, I used Italian seasoned breadcrumbs, I added garlic powder because I didn't have enough fresh, and we grilled the patties. This time the mix was slightly firmer than hamburger and very easy to work with and I did not freeze patties prior to grilling. Texture after grilling was much better and the flavor was stronger.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing!  There are a couple of things that I have done differently--  I like to add a jalapeño in with the green pepper and onion for a little extra flavor, I only use one teaspoon of cumin instead of a tablespoon, I like to add about 1/2-1 cup of corn in with the black beans, and I use bread crumbs and oatmeal to make the mixture (I use a lot more bread crumbs than the recipe calls for, I just add them until I get a good consistency/texture). I highly recommend that you drain the green pepper/onion mixture as much as possible so that there isn't too much moisture in the burger mix.  To cook them I first bake them in the oven (as directed) and then I cook them on medium-high in a skillet for 2-4 minutes on each side to crisp them up.  These burgers taste wonderful and are very much worth the effort and time it takes to make them.

text:
Really great. My young kids (4 & 6) love them and so do I. Changes I made:
2 eggs (not 1), 
2 tsp cumin (1 just isn't enough, 1 Tblsp may work), 
1-3 tsp salt, 
1 Tbspn sugar, 
1/2 carrot shredded, 
1/2 zucchini shredded, 
3 shakes Italian seasoning, 
3/4 cup oat flour instead of bread crumbs, 
6 cloves of garlic, 
1/2 cup sweet corn (frozen), 
Omitted all chili sauce/powder (my kids won't tolerate it yet).

It's a winner!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these tonight, and they turned out so well that I helped myself to a second one despite that I was already full from "round one".  I had a hard time mashing up the beans "manually", so I threw them into the food processor along with the onion, pepper and garlic once I had chopped them separately.  The end consistency was quite smooth, and I became worried that I would be making some sort of black bean meatloaf instead because the mixture did not appear as though it would be amenable to being formed into patties.  But once I added the bread crumbs (I added probably twice as much as the recipe calls for), the patties formed just fine.  I grilled the burgers on our indoor grill, and served with the usual burger toppings.  I am by no means vegetarian, but for health reasons am trying to eat less meat and incorporate more legumes into my diet.  This recipe will definitely remain on my radar!  Just awesome!

*UPDATE*...I think I've mastered these.  What I do is mince the veggies in the food processor first, then add the black beans and pulse a few times.  Stir in everything else "manually", and then I'm good to go.  I actually prefer these to meat burgers now, so much cheaper and healthier!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-07-03T15:15:51.473
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
13859427
Display Name:
Kayleigh
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1220264.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took Eliza's review into consideration when making these.  I did alter a few things, but OMG these things are fantastic!!!  I made a triple batch for a July 4th BBQ, and I don't know if they will make it to tomorrow!

Here is what I did:
I drained and rinsed the beans, then spread them on a cookie sheet and baked them about 20 minutes at 350*.  They got a bit crunchy, which is oh so good.

I put a handful of mushrooms, a giant sweet onion, a whole head of garlic, a bunch of cilantro, and about a dozen small sweet peppers (unfortunately I used all of my jalapenos in my mango jalapeno chutney) in the blender, added about 4 egg whites, and the zest and juice of a lime.  I tossed in the dried baked beans and salt and pepper, and blended til' smooth.  

Poured this into a bowl and added a tsp of each: chipotle powder, white pepper, and cumin, and a pinch of salt and a pinch of regular chili powder.

Here the mix was very wet, so I started with a 1/2c bread crumbs.  Still wet, so I added about 1c rolled oats. Still wet, so I added 4Tbsp flour.  This seemed good (Every mix will have a different moisture content, so just keep adding until it works), so I managed to make 16 patties, plus a taster.  

I put the patties on oiled foil in the oven at 350* for about 20 minutes (was no longer spongy/puffy to the touch), let them cool a bit, and now I have them on cookie racks to cool before I freeze them (wax paper btwn.) I HOPE they hold up on the BBQ tomorrow!  If not, I will reheat.

text:
I followed the suggestion to strain the onion-green pepper mixture and I rinsed the beans...the flavor of the burgers was great & they held together pretty good, but they have a weird texture. After cooking them according to directions, the outside edge of the burgers was dry...the middle was better. I don't think not straining the vegs would help much bc the already delicate texture if the patty would be downright falling apart. I thought they were just ok...my friend who eats veg & black bean burgers regularly liked them more than I did, but still found them a little dry. Overall, just ok and I probably won't make them again.

text:
These turned out great! My husband is not a vegetarian, but loved them. I doubled the recipe so I could freeze more leftovers. I followed other reviewers' advice for keeping the patties in tact and patted the beans dry, added 50% more bread crumbs, and added an egg (50% more for a double batch). The patties stuck together perfectly. I also added corn -- yum. I used plain bread crumbs, but flavored or salted might be better. Also, next time I'll add a little more chili sauce or chili oil because I'd personally prefer a little more of a kick. Regardless, these were terrific.

text:
After reading several reviews, I made this recipe with a few tweaks and it turned out great!  I cut down on the cumin using half the suggested amount and added a half teaspoon of salt. I added a jalapeno pepper diced/minced and at the suggestion of a local restaurant whose black bean burgers rock, I used crushed up Dorito chips rather than bread crumbs.  I grilled half of the burgers and baked half but cut the cooking time to 8 minutes a side rather than 10.  The burgers turned out great both ways - my family loved them and I will be making these again!

userID:
12286665
Display Name:
Doctor Keys
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really love this recipe!

It is excellent as written (I add salt to taste, BTW) and also serves as a template for variations.  I've found that almost any addition of a low-moisture and highly flavorful ingredient helps to add a personal touch.  I have tried these add-ons alone or in a combination (the variety is endless!): fresh or dried minced parsley, basil, oregano, red pepper flakes, paprika, turmeric, coriander, ground mustard seed, minced sun-dried tomatoes, mushroom, black or green olives, celery seed, taco seasoning, Italian seasoning, Italian dressing mix, ranch dressing mix, chili mix, et alia.  I could go on but you get the idea; any flavorful and/or aromatic ingredient to your liking would work, used in place of or in addition to the original vegetables and spices (just so long as it's not too moist).  Vegetable add-ons with more moisture such as corn, salsa or shredded carrot require some pre-treatment to remove the excess water; for example, I like to add a little salt to shredded carrot or zucchini, allowing some water to seep out, followed by pressing and draining through a wire mesh strainer.  

It's important to keep the moisture content relatively unchanged when making alterations, IMO. As long as the wet and dry components are in balance, your own version(s) should work. 

But after all that, I still like the original. It has a Tex-Mex taste that I really like!

These were pretty good.  I would have liked them to be spicier.  I did freeze them first.  They took quite a long time to cook in the oven.  I added more breadcrumbs according to one of the reviews, but I wish I hadn't because I found the burgers to be very bland.  I didn't squeeze out the veggie mixture because it was all taking too long.  I will keep trying this to hone my recipe.  It's a good recipe to get you started if you've never made them before, like me.

text:
I have made this recipe several times. Usually as is, sometimes with half-ground oats instead of breadcrumbs.  This time I diced the onion and bell pepper by hand. I cut 1/4 strips then squeezed with a paper towel before finishing the knife-work. This was the first time I have not needed more breadcrumbs/oats! I always try to wring out the liquid after processing, but it's pretty difficult to do. Will dice by hand from now on. Also, I dropped cumin to 3 tsp, as it is otherwise a bit much for my taste. Made this as the vegetarian option for friends at a cookout - rave reviews :)

I read through many of the reviews before making this recipe.  I took others advice and squeezed the excess water from the bell pepper and onion mixture.  I also dried the beans off.  The recipe was easy to make and absolutely delicious!  I can't understand why anyone would have problems with it.  One thing I did do was put the mixture in the refrigerator for a couple of hours.  I'm not sure if that helped any, but I had no problems forming the patties.  The burgers were moist and better than store bought brands.  I will definitely be making this one again.  Thanks!

text:
This was really good I am a true blue carnivore but I have say that I enjoyed this recipe. I have tried other veggie burgers before and idi not like them. The recipe was easy to follow and all I did was follow some of the other suggestions. The only things I did differently was to grate my garlic and I grated half of the onion then I followed a suggestion to mix ritz crackers and oatmeal instead of bread crumbs also I put that in the mix and let it sit for 15 min to soak up extra liquid. I added a little liquid smoke and worchestshire sauce these came out good I will be making these again I might add an extra grain like quinoa to add a little more structure. Which will give it a bit more texture like a real burger.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this recipe! It's a total staple in my house now. I quadruple it (it's only marginally more work than just making the single recipe) and store them in the freezer with a piece of wax paper between each one (all in a big ziploc bag or two), and then we have easy lazy weeknight dinners when we need them! I make some small adjustments with the spices. I use 1 TSP cumin, not one TBSP (and I love cumin, but 1 TSP is plenty!), and same with the chili powder. Also, as other reviewers mentioned, the trick is to make sure the beans are drained dry and to drain the veggie mixture so the mix isn't too wet. It makes kind of a mess (I use paper towels, lots and lots of paper towels) but it's totally worth it. These are just so incredibly good, you can't compare with anything store bought, and they are really low-fat and healthy too!

This is a tasty recipe.  Why so many different opinions as to whether the burgers will hold together?  Well, the wetness of the veggies and beans is variable...so cooks must use some common sense and tweaks when putting these burgers together.   I doubled the beans and bread crumbs in the recipe but only needed a single recipe  of peppers, onions and garlic.  Used double recipe of seasoning and added a couple tablespoons dried cilantro.  My family enjoyed these veggie burgers.  Thanks LAURENMU!

These burgers were surprisingly good (note: I'm not vegetarian and generally not a bold cook). I added corn and cilantro (suggestion from a similar recipe), and I used Panko break crumbs. I will cook these again.

text:
Very good.  I added the extra egg like suggested in comments, and cut the cumin to 1 tsp.  I also added about 2-3 tbsp extra bread crumbs because of the additional egg.  Next time I would intentionally let the mixture set for 10-15 minutes fefore cooking to let it become easier to work with.  The last few I made were much better than the first.  

Also I wanted to grill them, so I started them in a pan on the stove so they would set and not fall through the grill.  :)  Worked wonderfully. 

The beans I used were Blue Runner Creole Cream-style Black Beans (my new favorite canned beans!)  OMG they are so good!

A single recipe made 8 smaller burgers.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just used this recipe, BUT the key (when baking) is to bake them for the first 10 minutes on 375 as suggested, then broil them on LO for 10 minutes, flip and continue broiling on LO for 5 minutes. The consistency of the mixture is really liquidy at first, but the broiling really solidifies them well. I topped mine with a slice of mozzarella and 1/2 of an avocado. To quote my vegetarian girlfriend "This is honestly the BEST veggie burger I have EVER had!" I will definitely be adding this recipe to the weekly dinner rotation :)

Used a red bell instead of green.  Other than that, made it exactly as the recipe says.  They were great.  My wife has never had a black bean burger and didn't love it, but my 4 year old son loved it, and I thought they put the MSF frozen ones to shame, and were much cheaper as well.  Next time I make them I will make a bigger batch and freeze them.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were quite tasty. I am not a big fan of onions or peppers, but I'm trying to eat better, so I used onions and peppers anyway. I doubled the recipe and used a whole orange bell pepper and a whole small white onion. Because my husband isn't a big fan of onions or peppers either, I put them in my food processer and kept going until they were really finely chopped and they added a nice flavor without having large chunks. I used dried beans I had cooked in a slow cooker, so I didn't have a lot of extra liquid. I froze the patties for about an hour before pan frying one, and baking the others. Both ways turned out great. I also made homemade burger buns for these, and THEY WERE AMAZING. I used the "Burger or Hot Dog Buns" recipe from here, and they took these to a whole new level. Overall, it was a good recipe, though I did end up using 1.5 times the bread crumbs like other reviewers have reported. I will likely try these again with cooked brown rice or quinoa in place of the bread crumbs to improve the nutrition.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
These black bean burgers were very tasty! Super easy to make. My five year old boy had fun smashing the black beans.:) After chopping the veggies in my blender, I strained them very well. I added more bread crumbs as recommended by other reviewers. I froze the burgers for about 45 minutes before baking in the oven. This recipe made 4 average size patties. I let the patties cool for about 10 minutes after baking. The patties were still pretty delicate. Easy to break apart. If you like store bought black bean burgers, you will love these! They taste exactly like the ones I bought from costco...just fresh tasting and not hard like the costco ones always were. Next time I make these, I will be adding corn and chop my veggies by hand so the patties have a bit more texture.

I didn't have any issues with the burgers being to wet, they held together perfectly for me. However I did make them on the stove top and not on the grill, which may have had something to do with it working out better for me then for others. I put in bread crumbs until the burgers became the consistency that I needed them to be, which happened to be less then what was called for. The thing with recipes is that everyone has different products that they are using so of course some alterations will have to be made in order for the end result to come out the way you want them to. Play around with your ingredients.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe. TEXTURE: I wish it was a little more meaty in texture like some of the frozen brands. I AM a vegetarian, but I am a new one (one month to be exact), so I still like the texture of meat in my burgers, but the bean-y texture was very good, too--just different. TIME: It took a little longer to make than it was supposed to because I don't have a food processor and my food "chopper" was turning it into liquid (I don't know if that was supposed to happen), so I took it out before it was too late and chopped the rest by hand. Chopping by hand meant more time in the kitchen, and plus the burgers were a bit chunkier than I preferred. They were still very good. I added a tablespoon of Egg Beaters to it to make it stick together. It tasted good, and unfortunately nobody in my home wanted to try it, so I was alone in my enjoyment of these burgers (is that really a bad thing?). 

I gave this recipe 5 stars because although the texture was not exactly perfect to me, this is a veggie burger and I realize it isn't supposed to taste like meat.
 
Update: I chopped the vegetables in the blender, which was probably a big mistake because it made it basically liquid. Will chop by hand next time because I don't have a real food processor.

These are great. Didn't want/have breadcrumbs so I pulsed some old fashioned oats in food processor instead (not flour, but no flakes either). When mixture was still too moist, I threw in some oat bran until texture was right. Followed advice and blotted beans of excess water. Puréed veggies in processor, then added beans and pulsed. Freeze. Grill or bake in individual foil packets at BBQ...

text:
These are ridiculously delicious burgers - even my carnivorous friends couldn't get enough of them. Five stars for taste, four stars for the recipe as it stands. As is, the patties are pretty loose and fall apart, even after baking or grilling. I ended up adding an entire cup of bread crumbs and a half cup of oats. The egg held up, and I didn't have to add any more spices (well,  maybe cumin, says the cumin addict...). I also used black beans that I had previously cooked from dried stock and frozen. A great way to use up left-overs! These will definitely become a staple in our home.

userID:

Display Name:
MommaFrankic
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Per recommendations from previous reviews, I made some alterations. I used a food processor to chop up the pepper and onion very fine and then drained the juices. I also rinsed and dried the black beans before mushing. Added 1.5 times the amount of bread crumbs (or oatmeal in my case because I never have bread crumbs) to help the patties stay together. Once I made the patties, I put them in the freezer. Pulled out of the freezer a few minutes before grilling. I sprayed some foil and folded over each individual patty and grilled that way. They stayed together perfectly, and have been delicious each time I have made this recipe. This is quite a bit of mess during the prep (when you have two kids "helping" you), so I always double the recipe and freeze 1/2 of the patties so I can just pull out of the freezer and grill. One of my family's favorite recipes!!

userID:
9086868
Display Name:
D23
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'll never buy store-bought veggie burgers again! I've used this recipe as a base for many different burgers.  My personal note: they seem to do  better with a little extra breadcrumbs and a little olive oil added to the mix; the extra breadcrumbs make patties easier to handle and the oilve oil keeps them moist.  that said, you can basically add whatever seasonings you like; Mexican, Italian, Asian, spicy or mild (I always double the recipe and save out a little for my three year old before adding anything too spicy).  I've even made 'meatballs' by putting in Italian seasonings and parm. then rolling them into balls instead of patties. You may need to experiment with cooking times, which will vary depending on the size of the pattie/loaf/balls, but it seems to closely coincide with that of meat dishes of the same ilk.

text:
We liked this recipe very much! I would recommend doubling the recipe. I am not a big fan of peppers, so only used 1/2 of what was called for, and my husband, the pepper lover, still liked them. 
No problem with the burgers falling apart, but I did mash all the ingredients together by hand to get them fully incorporated. It really did look a bit like chunky hummus when I was through hand-mixing it. 
I baked mine in the oven in an olive oil coated pan with good results. Excellent with sour cream!

text:
As written 4 stars.  1/3 kids found this a little spicy so I will play with the seasoning next time.  Definitely needed to increase the bread crumbs in the mix to get a better consistency.  When baked, did not crisp on the outside, so texture was a little off for the meat-eaters in the crowd.  Would recommend a quick, light fry to get the outside a little crisper.  Definitely serve with toasted buns and lettuce to get a little more texture as well.  Will be adding this to the regular rotation.

Today I'm eating it with spaghetti sauce and cheddar.  I froze the other 6.  This is a new item to add to my rotation. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/802886.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These weren't bad at all and it was super easy to make! I followed the advice from previous reviews and it's important to strain the pepper, garlic, onion, and black bean mixture! What helped was adding about 1/4 cup of bread crumbs and about 1/4 cup-1/3 cup of oatmeal. It held together really nicely. I also changed up the spices: 1 tbl of chili powder, .5 tbl of paprika, .5 tbl of cumin, 1/2 tsp of garlic pepper, and 1.5 tsp of chili garlic sauce. Sounds like a lot but it didn't over power the patty at all. Will definitely make again!

PS
baked sweet potatoes would be a great side to this dish!

text:
These are great to make and freeze for quick lunches. I eat mine topped with hot sauce or salsa, a little bit of melted cheddar, and a smidge of sour cream. Good eaten on and off a roll. I followed others' suggestions and made sure to rinse and dry the beans and strain the onion/garlic/green pepper mixture. Mine stayed together fine. Next time I might make it less dry, add some chili peppers and use it as a burrito filling.

text:
Added 3x the amount of breadcrumbs to get it to hold together.  Decreased the amount of cumin and chili powder by a teaspoon, because of all the reviews, but should have left the recipe as is!  Added fresh cilantro and 1/2 a minced jalapeno, and the patties were STILL a bit bland.  Will make again, but with MORE not less spices. Comparable to store bought black bean burgers, but not better.

text:
Amazing veggie burgers!!  Better than Morning Star burgers.  I love veggie burgers, but I really like to know EXACTLY what is in my food (and save money) which makes this recipe an A+.  This is a seriously delicious, though I did make some minor alterations to make it fit my tastes better

Added 2x the cumin, extra garlic powder ( I love garlic, what can I say), used yellow peppers instead of green (that's what I had on hand) added about 3 slices of bread (crumbled) to give it a better consistancy, added about 3/4 tablespoon chipotle Tabasco, also added a dash of Italian seasoning and various other savory spice mixes to give it a well rounded flavor and instead of baking it, I dipped them in flour and fried them (OMG, delicious!). 

WILL DEFINIETLY MAKE AGAIN!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My 4-year old loved it so that alone says it all!  Easy to make!  I put in 1/4 T chili powder because i was concerned it would be too hot for my son.  1/2 T cumin only and 1/2 T sweet chili sauce.  I did add 1/2 a cup of bread crumbs and thought it was too watery still, so I crumbled in some extra crackers we had on hand.  I agree that the beans need to be drained of excess water, but most importantly, after you have the ingredients mixed up, you have to judge for yourself:  if it's too watery and looks like it might be too hard to hold together, add more to bulk it up!  Next time I'll try adding corn and perhaps different spices.  Have fun experimenting!

text:
These were so darn tasty!!  I must admit that they were a little tedious to make, solely because I don't have a food processor... so I spent a lot of time chopping the onion and green pepper, but even with the larger pieces of veggies, these were amazing!  My family all greatly enjoyed these!  The BF asked if they were fairly easy to make and I explained the chopping... He was disappointed in the time it took, but on the bright side, I believe we will be investing in a food processor soon!  I used garlic bread crumbs to help enhance the flavor a bit more, and omitted the chili sauce due to the spice level tolerance not being the same for everyone and they still had so much flavor with the cumin and chili power.  Thanks for a great recipe!!

text:
Well, let me just say that these are delicious!!!  I am not a vegetarian, but right now, I am in the process pf doing a detox and I am not allowed to have meat.  These burgers are so good, that when I am done with the detox, I will continue to eat them!  I followed the recipe exactly as it was written because this was my first time making it, and I will not be changing it in the future.  Not unless I want a little more spice!  I warmed up a 10' flour tortilla shell, used some of my Dad's homemade BBQ sauce, lettuce, shredded cheese and bread and butter pickles.  WOW!!  I cant wait to make these for my sister n law who is a vegetarian!  My meat loving kids even loved them!!

text:
my new years resolution is to go vegan so ive been doing it bit by bit.  my friend, who lives a few houses down, has chickens, though, so i do eat eggs from there.  thats what i used in this recipe.  i had to nearly double the amount of breadcrumbs, fried one and then decided i need still more breadcrumbs.  i also added salt and in addition to the chili sauce, i loaded it with sriracha sauce (i really like spicy!) i also added chopped onion and green pepper to the mixture which added a nice texture.  topped with vegan cheese in between two pieces of gluten free toast.  i only wish i had some salsa with this and maybe a slice of avocado.  it made way more than the four servings but now ive frozen them to eat throughout the week and share with friends.

I regularly make these burgers for church potluck. I double or triple the recipe, use lots of breadcrumbs (I seldom measure anything exactly) and bake. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe, and I hate to be redundant, but really is better than the frozen.  Was too mushy, but as my husband said, it was like a burrito filling.   "Fried" on top of stove in cast iron skillet with very little oil.  Will add more filler next time (flax? oatmeal? brown rice?).  Added frozen roasted corn kernels (Trader Joe's, I keep a bag in the freezer).  Served with an amazing spread we made up with mayo, sour cream, and oven-dried crushed jalapenos from our bumper crop.  When we had zillions of jalapenos, we dehydrated them in the oven then ran them through the food processor.  Nice heat when we need it.  Burger recipe definitely a keeper!

text:
These were really good, however, they were so spicy! I am used to some spice in my food, but these were almost too spicy to eat. I even thought about it as I was making them, thinking that 1 tablespoon of chili powder seemed like a lot. Next time I will definitely go lighter on the spices. I made 6 burgers out of mine because 4 made HUGE ones. I calculated each burger at 116 calories! Awesome low cal burger, just be careful and taste the mixture before hand. Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
My seriously carnivorous husband said that these are "better than regular burgers." They tasted fabulous! We topped them with avocado. I had a little difficulty with the consistency because I failed to read the directions carefully, and put the beans in the food processor rather than mashing them by hand. The batter was way too mushy to "form" anything. But I treated them like pancake batter, using a larger cookie scoop on an oiled iron skillet. Next time, I'll hope for better consistency (and follow directions!). These will definitely become a regular at our dinner table, and we aren't even vegetarians.

text:
Although slightly better the second day, overall I did not enjoy these and the recipe did not work as written. I had to add a lot more bread crumbs than was called for to even get anything resembling a very sticky patty to put on the baking sheet. I should have added another egg and squeezed out the water from the minced vegetables, but I wanted to rate and review this as it was written. 

The patties were very difficult to turn halfway through the cooking process due to their heavy wetness. It would probably have been easier and less frustrating to just pan fry them. Also, I did not care for the bland flavor or pasty texture. I'd much rather make burgers out of ground seitan (wheat gluten). Easier and tastier.

text:
I followed others' advice: cut spices to 1 tsp each; drained the veggies; added 1 minced jalapeno pepper instead of hot sauce, and added extra breadcrumbs and used 2 eggs.  And I pan fried in a tiny bit of olive oil.  OK sounds like a lot of changes but I still think it was tweaks.  They were very tasty (served in a whole wheat pita with fresh avocado slices) but I wasn't thrilled with the mashed bean texture.  Next time I will try adding corn as suggested by another review, and also maybe some cooked brown rice.  With a little extra texture these would be perfect!

city:

country:

text:
Oh my goodness are these fantastic!! I never thought they'd be this good. I've been making falafels lately & love them so I thought I'd try these burgers. I mashed up the beans the day b4 & left them in the fridge. I doubled the recipe, added a 1/2 can of mashed chick peas, a handful of crushed crackers in addition to the bread crumbs. I didn't have any onion so I put about 1/4 c. dried onion in some water to plump them up.  I coated with the breadcrumbs. I fried them in a little oil. 
Served with a sauce I whipped up: mayo, ranch, hot sauce, red pepper, paprika & cumin. Melted provolone & shredded cheddar on top of the burgers, topped with sauce. YUM! 
This will be a regular meal in our house now. I like this much better than regular burgers. Who knew eating meat-free meals could be so yummy?

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am a meat eater but am looking to cut calories so I wasn't sure what to expect out of this recipe since I have never had a veggie burger, but I love black beans so I thought I'd give it a try. I thought a whole tablespoon of chili powder and cumin for the amount of black beans/onion/bell pepper was just too much so I scaled that back to about 1 1/2 teaspoons, threw in a couple shakes of Steak N Shake seasoning and just a shake more bread crumbs to form the patties. The patties tasted very good but they taste like chili. They are like if you took chili and made a patty out of it. lol. After one taste of a cooked patty, I knew what to do with it.  I melted a little shredded cheese on top of one and added a little scoop of sour cream to it. These are very good but like I said they taste like chili in a patty. I definately think for my taste that 1 tablespoon of chili powder and cumin would have been way too much. I wanted to still taste the beans and already couldn't with what little amount of seasoning I used. I couldnt image eating this on a bun with lettace and tomatoe but I might try it.

city:

region:

country:

text:
Amazing! I made a few changes according to other reviewers: added 1/4 cup rolled oats, dried the beans, squeezed out the fluids and freezed them a night before cooking.

Also, I used only 1/2 tsp cumin because I don't really like it, didn't have any hot sauce so skipped it, added 1 shredded carrot (drained) and doubled the garlic. I did not use a food processor but a brown mixer, which left chunks of the black beans- I think this was a good call because the burger did not feel like a ball of refried beans, like other reviewers said.. 

Next time I'm probably going to triple the recipe and freeze them to have great veggie burgers on hand..!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-06-24T21:20:14.347
helpfulCount:
1

Display Name:
aisle4

region:
None
country:
None
text:
1) Rinse, strain, and dry the black beans WELL before mashing.

2) Use mounded 1/4c mix in a burger press *lined with plastic wrap* to get good consistent patties.  If you don't line with plastic wrap the mix will be stuck in the press.

3) Add 1/4c processed carrots and 1 tbsp fresh ginger.

...Delicious, thanks!

country:
None
text:
Before making this recipe, I never had more than a single bite of a black bean burger. I wasn't very impressed with the one that I tasted. This recipe is delicious! I don't know if all of the measurements wound up being exact, but I did use all of the same ingredients (minus the onion) and added a little extra here and there to taste, adding the egg last. I had no problem with it holding together. I allowed the beans to sit in a strainer for about 10 minutes, and then froze the patties for about 20 minutes while I worked on sweet potato fries. I then grilled them on a George Forman. The patties were fairly spicy and delicious, and I paired them with a homemade avocado spread on a toasted wheat bun with lettuce and thin slice of tomato. Yum!

text:
These were delicious - the seasoning is just right! My first attempt followed the recipe exactly - I tried to grill them and they fell apart! This afternoon, I made a few modifications: used red bell pepper, red onion, and homemade wheat breadcrumbs. I sauteed the bell pepper and onion in 1T of olive oil, then mashed the blackbeans with a potato masher. I combined all ingredients (I ending up using 2 slices of bread for the crumbs, which equaled about 1 cup. Cooked in a cast iron skillet with 1 T of olive oil. So good! You've got to try these with pickles and swiss cheese!

Display Name:
Fra

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not knowing what to expect, I was pleasantly surprised how easy and good they were. I drained the beans and mashed them with a fork and added a tablespoon or more of salsa.(I didn't have the chili sauce) I chopped 1/2 orange pepper, 1/2 onion and three cloves of garlic in my blender. Added the cumin and chili powder. Added that mixture plus the egg to the beans and then added 1/2 cup bread crumbs. I also added some fresh chopped parsley. Mixed it and formed patties. They formed well and did not break apart. I baked them as directed on lightly oiled parchment ... 8 minutes each side. Very tasty, very simple!

userID:

Display Name:
Joyce

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had no business starting this recipe...no black beans, no bread crumbs, no green (or red) pepper, so I did what I always do..improvise.  Cut cumin to 1 tsp because I felt that a tablespoon was overkill.  Used a can of red kidney beans, drained and rinsed.  Used instant masa instead of bread crumbs.  Shaped into six thin patties and fried in a nonstick skillet in just a whisper of oil.  I had some homemade whole wheat buns to use and we topped the burgers with some pickled onion slices, mayo, dijon, and spinach leaves.  My daughter and I both gave this a thumbs up.  The patties weren't mushy at all and this is a great vegetarian dish.

I prepared the burgers by cutting up the onion, bell pepper and garlic with a knife. I also decided to cut up some mushrooms then I added all of the veggies to the mashed beans. text:
These were fantastic. Even my carnivore boyfriend loved them. I listened to some of the comments and used 2 eggs instead of 1, and also added more breadcrumbs. I also squeezed out the excess liquid from the onion mixture and as much as I could from the beans. I cooked them in the oven and at the end I shallow pan fried them for about 30 seconds on each side. I topped them with avocado, pepperjack cheese, and I made a little chipotle mayo. Used a few tbls of mayo and liquid from chipotle in adobo, and also added chipotles diced. So delicious. Thanks Laurenmu!

text:
Great thing to add to BBQ for veggie (and non veggie) friends!  Tofu dogs are pretty gross and I dont want to serve frozen pre-made patties. I made mixture the night before, minus the hot sauce and bread crumbs (red bell pepper instead of green), then added 3/4 c bread crumbs and 2 T of the green tabasco at the last minute.  I made them into mini-burgers and grilled them on my tabletop grill/pannini press just like any old burger. They held together great and everyone who ate them complemented them. Great with pepperocini peppers, salsa, and a little cheese.

text:
Warning- you will be shocked by how delicious these burgers are!!!  I didn't have any trouble with the burgers falling apart- one suggestion- skip step 2, and add the beans (strained and rinsed) into the food processor after step 3.  Pulse until well mixed.  Add more breadcrumbs if they are too watery to form a decent patty.  You can play around with the seasoning- I omitted the hot sauce and half of the chili powder, and added other seasonings.  So healthy and delicious I'd give it 10 stars if I could!

text:
I followed the exact ingredients of this recipe.  The only thing I changed was the method.  On the RE Marcella told me to mince my veggies in the food processor and then just throw the beans in too and pulse them until I had the right consistency.  So I did just that.  I have to admit, all the reviews scared me with their watery vegetables and the patties that wouldn't hold their shape.  I did not have that problem at all!  Mine made beautiful patties and held together quite well.  I baked them 12 minutes on parchment paper and then flipped them and baked 12 more minutes.  A very enjoyable nutritious, healthy burger. ***The second time I had to bake them longer, long enough to get a crisp crust on each side.

text:
I enjoyed this recipe a lot...the rest of my family wouldn't even try them, but I didn't expect that this recipe would appeal to everyone.  I would make these again, but I'll play around with the seasonings as I am not a big fan of cumin.  I reduced the cumin to 1 tsp, but next time I'd eliminate it, add a little black pepper, and increase the Thai chili sauce.  I used Safeway Nut and Grain bread to make my breadcrumbs, and I liked having little bits of nuts in the burgers as well.  My mixture was very liquid (I blotted my drained beans with a paper towel) so I just poured it into 4 little, greased foil trays that I made and baked it without flipping.  It resembled a vegetarian meatloaf slice.

text:
Excellent black bean burgers!  I have been making a version of these for many years, but there were some problems with the old recipe I had used and I was looking for one that was better.  This is it!   I was in a hurry, so I skipped chopping the veggies and instead used a fresh salsa (squeezed very dry).  With that step, these were in the oven in ten minutes flat.  Super quick and easy!  I did not have any problem with them falling apart, and the texture was perfect--not too moist, not too dry.  I served them with a lime-cumin mayo on the homemade burger buns from this site, with lettuce and tomato.  Yum!  Will definitely make these again.  Thanks!

Display Name:
Megan Schroder
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6576206.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was SUCH a great recipe! I followed the recipe exactly, except for a few things. As others suggested, I rinsed the beans thoroughly and dried them with a paper towel. I added about 1/3 a can of corn, and used red pepper instead of green. I used my Slap Chop to do the onions and red pepper and this worked SO well. Before I added the red pepper, I squeezed them of their juices. you must eliminate as much water as you can. From doing this, I found I only needed 1 egg - others mentioned they needed 2. I formed the patties and put them in the freezer for about an hour to make handling easier. I grilled them on the BBQ on tin foil as suggested - worked great, even had grill marks like real burgers.   Instead of using ketcup and mustard and regular burger toppings, I used homemade guacamole (I figured this would go since the burgers have a bit of a tex mex flavour). The guac really made it! SO GOOD!!! I also served the burgers on those new whole grain thin buns. Was delish.   Thanks for such an awesome recipe! I'm not a vegetarian... but this will definitely be a staple in my house!
