text:
This is a great recipe and I enjoyed the burgers A LOT even though I'm not a vegetarian.  However, I did make a few alterations.  As suggested by other reviewers I rinsed and slightly dried the beans before mashing as well as refigerated the formed burgers for several hours.  I was feeding these to young children so I skipped the hot sauce and added ketchup and worchestershire instead.  Also halfed the amount of cumin and chili powder which I definitey recommend as it was sufficient.  Corn also adds a nice sweet element.

My husband and I loved these burgers. We had them last night for supper and paired them with onion rings and dark beer. YUM! So, for us, the mixture made 8 burgers. We will definitely have these again!

text:
This recipe is pretty good. The only changes I made was to use red pepper and dice it finely, sautee the diced onion prior to mixing. I didn't have any garlic or chili sauce. Otherwise I followed the recipe exactly. I think I will use a little less cumin next time, as I found it to be a little overpowering. Also, the bread crumbs I used were a little too fine, which resulted in a gummy texture. I will try another reviewer's suggestion of oats, or crispier bread crumbs. I didn't have a problem rolling these into patties, but they did come out a little dry. I associate this with the bread crumbs. Topped burger with cheese and avacodo. Mmm. Great healthy recipe!

text:
YUM!  I had leftover black beans so I made these last night--they're so easy to make and tasted great on a bun with lettuce, cheese, and mayo. I didn't have chili sauce so I threw in barbecue sauce instead.  The burger mush was a bit loose at first so I just kept adding breadcrumbs.  The rest are in the freezer and I hope to make more soon!

3/13/11 Made these again.  drained the beans really well and dried them before mashing.  Cut up 3 slices onion, 4 slices red pepper (frozen) and two large baby bella mushrooms into very small pieces, then dried with a paper towel.  mashed up beans in hand food processor with chili powder, garlic powder, cumin, and taco seasoning.  Added 2 ketchup packets.  Mixed in egg, then veggies, then 2.5 capfulls of breadcrumbs (~ 1/2 cup).  Made 6 patties.

city:

country:
None
text:
Okay, I  am in so happy that this recipe is everything and more than I could have hoped for.  I am pretty new to burger substitutes, so I was a little nervous. This recipe is amazing! My picky carnivorous husband gobbled one down with cheese as soon as I took them out of the oven. They smelled so good! I did make some minor changes...  I was out of chili powder so I added a dash of Tabasco, 1/8 tsp paprika and a dash of cayenne pepper along with the Thai chili sauce and cumin. The burgers were terrific this way so I doubt I will  ever make them with chili powder. Also I used Sarah Lee 45 cal bread for my crumbs to save a few calories.I sprayed the burgers with a little Pam to prevent sticking. I baked them at 375 for 10 min on each side. Mine held together fine just be careful. Let them sit for a few minutes and they should be fine. Thanks for the recipe. I will definitely make these again and again! Freeze the leftovers!

I have never eaten a store bought veggie burger, so I have no point of reference, but these were awesome! Probably took 20 minutes from finding this recipe until I had them on the table!  I'm going to mix up a huge batch and put them in the freezer for easy grabbing.

I didn't have a problem with the burgers sticking together, I made sure to dry the beans after I rinsed them but didn't strain the garlic/onion/pepper before adding it.  I did add some extra bread crumbs to compensate (only about 1/8 cup).  They tasted good but the texture is too mushy to go on a burger - it squeezed off the edges of the bun as I was eating.  My husband said not to make them again, he felt like he was eating a burrito on a bun.   I might make them again just for myself for lunches but maybe put it in a wrap or play around with the texture more.

text:
The reason I rated so low is I don't find this recipe to be good for veggie burgers.  I've tried it twice now; the 1st time it was very runny and ended up using it as stuffing for tacos like another user suggested.  The 2nd time; I managed to get the mixture dry enough by following some of the other suggestion on the board.  However, I still find it too mushy for a veggie burger; this is best for making tacos or tortilla stuffing but not for veggie burger making.      As for the veggies to stuff; I used onions, celery and red pepper mixture which worked well and the hot sauce is the right amount; just enough to give it a kick.  I also recommend to freeze before cooking to keep it from falling apart.

text:
I made these vegan by omitting the egg and adding 2 tablespoons of whole wheat flour to make the whole mixture come together.  If you omit the egg like I did the first time, you'll end up with really mushy batter (like mashed potatoes).  I fried them in olive oil for a special treat.  I didn't have any hot sauce on hand, so I added ketchup instead, which might not be the best substitute, but the burger didn't lack any flavour.  Instead of garlic, I added a tsp of granulated garlic for more subtle taste.  Very good.  I think I might even add vegan steak spices in next time for some punch.

text:
I made these the way it was written the first time and they were very good. However, I have since then made some changes that made them fabulous for my tastes. I did add an extra egg, I don't put in the fresh veggies I use powdered to flavor(just easier for me) I also changed the spices to better suit the flavor I was looking for. I am not vegetarian, I just wanted a healthier substitute for my primary addiction(cheeseburgers) as I am on a strict diet now. I use liquid smoke, worchestershire sauce, and beef bouillion to flavor the burgers to get a beefier flavor. I also plan to use oat flour instead of bread crumbs next time I make these to make them even better for you. Hopefully they will still turn out good. These satisfy my craving for a burger every time, and this is healthy to boot. LOVE and highly recommend this recipe even for meat lovers like me.

text:
First let me say I am not a fan of most veggie burgers, but I am trying to lose weight, and go meatless for a meal or 2 a week to cut down on fat. I made this pretty much as written, used pepper and onion stirfry mix well drained in a food chopper, and used Mrs Dash steak seasoning, as it had most of the ingredients of your seasonings, added a bit more cumin. They came out perfect, didn't stick, formed patties very well, while a bit dry adding some light mayo to the burger made it quite tasty, flavor stayed for a long time. Thanks for posting I think I will make some and keep in the freezer.

text:
NO complaints! This was absolutely delicious. I forgot the hot sauce in the recipe, but there was plenty of flavor (I did add just a little salt and pepper to taste prior to adding the egg). I topped with cheese, lettuce, tomato and pickles, just like I would a regular burger. The flavor was good enough, though, that you wouldn't HAVE to add anything. I added the beans to the food processor, after the pepper/onions/etc. were chopped well. I had no problems with the burgers falling apart or sticking to the pan, as others have mentioned. I used non-stick cooking spray on my baking sheet. I'm wondering if some reviewers didn't mash the beans up enough to get a pasty texture. I will make this again...and again!!!

text:
Love these burgers. I use two eggs and probably 1 cup of bread crumbs, and I think they're perfect. I have tried both grilling on aluminum foil and frying, and both are good, although the burgers are a little harder to deal with when frying. I top them with with store-bought hot and spicy mayo, a little ranch, cheddar, lettuce, and guacamole. Salsa is also good on them, but seriously, it's worth the extra effort to put the guac on. Also, I make five patties instead of four because I think they're too mushy in the middle if you make them that thick.

text:
This was a great base recipe!  I used creamed corn instead of eggs (we are vegan) upped the bread crumbs by 50% as other users suggested (I use Panko) added 2 TBSP flax seeds and 1/4 cup shredded carrots, used 2 bunchs of green onions and 4 cloves garlic.  Ommited the chili flavorings (personal preference). I baked them 7 min each side then lightly sauteed in olive oil.  Served on whole wheat english muffins toasted with garlic-butter and a side of sweet potato fries - it really hit the spot!

text:
Next time I make these I intend on making some changes based on a couple of difficulties I experienced. I had absolutely no problem forming the patties even though I left out the egg (I'm allergic). I thought the consistency of the mixture was perfect, not at all sticky and quite similar to turkey burgers I've made in the past. However, I had a hard time keeping them from falling apart during cooking (I baked them unfrozen and frozen) and had to keep reforming them during the cooking process. I also found these to be quite dry(could be because I left out the egg?) and not substantial enough for a burger. Otherwise, I loved the taste of them and thought the spice was perfect! I melted some cheddar on them and served with a modified version of the "Chipotle Peach Salsa with Cilantro."

I tried this recipe in an effort to use some leftover black beans (dried ones, soaked and cooked). I was very pleased with this! I didn't have breadcrumbs, so after some research I used cornmeal. text:
These burgers are excellent! Even my carnivore husband loved these.   To make the burgers a little healthier, I put oatmeal in the food processor instead of using breadcrumbs. To keep the burgers from falling apart, I used two eggs and just over a cup of ground oatmeal. After mixing all of the ingredients together, I refrigerated the mixture for just over an hour. Everything held together perfectly! We used red pepper instead of green pepper, because we much prefer that flavor. These burgers were delicious, and we will make them again and again!

country:
None
text:
I've never really had veggie burgers before, so I wasn't sure what to expect. I thought they were good, but not fantastic. I doubled the recipe and took the beans for a ride in the salad spinner to dry off. I used 50% more bread crumbs as advised by a different reviewer. I think that is a good suggestion because they did stay together well. It is cold outside, so I used the oven rather than the grill. My family didn't eat these as well as I expected even though they LOVE black beans, so I will be the solo veggie burger leftover consumer. I do think there was too much cumin. If I make these again (probably not) I will reduce the cumin in half. These would be really good with some chipotle mayo or something similar.

text:
Great! Easy enough recipe, great results. I was a little put off by reports of oddly-textured burgers, so I added an extra 1/2 egg per recipe (I doubled it, so I added one egg) and added a combination of bread crumbs and oats until the bean mixture was no longer moist and sticky. If you pay attention to the state of the "dough" and don't cook until it feels right you should be fine! Per other reviewers' suggestion I topped with Chipotle Mayo from this site and it really added good flavor. I also served with Roasted Vegetables from this site for a healthy veg meal. Thanks for a recipe I'll return to again and again!

Display Name:
PinkPenguinStar

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:

text:
This is the second time I've made this. The first time was quite a long while ago. Today I made sure to rinse and dry all the vegetables. I added in 1/3 - 1/2 cup corn and a small can of fire roasted green chiles. I mixed the beans with the spices first. I added 1 tbsp cumin, 2 tsp chili powder, 1 tsp garlic pepper, 1 tsp of my own chipotle spice mix, and a few shakes of liquid smoke. After I mixed that well, I took all the vegetables (which I chopped the onion and bell pepper finely -- the garlic I left whole) and put them in a bread loaf pan, mixed in some olive oil, and roasted them for awhile. I drained the vegetables after removing them and added them to the bean mixture. I pressed the garlic and mixed well. Instead of bread crumbs, I used 1/2 cup oats (run through the blender slightly), and wheat germ (oh, I have no idea how much -- I just added til it looked right, 1/3 cup maybe?). Instead of an egg, I used 2 tbsp ground flaxseed + 6 tbsp water, mixed. I added that last. I sprayed a lined baking sheet with Pam, sprayed my hands, and formed patties (then sprayed the tops of them). I got 6 good sized (but thinner) patties. All vegan too! For the rest of my family, I made up some chipotle mayo as suggested by other reviewers. I glanced at the recipe, but I didn't follow it exactly. I used a big glop of mayo, a big squirt of ranch, and most of a chipotle bouillion cube. Cumin was perfect, I thought.

I'm not a vegetarian and I won't give up meat burgers, but I thought these were very good and I'll definitely make them again.  I shaped mini-burgers and grilled them on my indoor griddle with just a bit of nonstick spray. userID:

Display Name:
Ka.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  They ended up smelling and tasting like taco seasoning!  I made these for my fiance and his mother and his vegetarian sister.  We LOVED them.  They are still enjoyable two days later, too.  I made a few changes, though:
-I doubled the recipe
-I used an extra egg
-I used an extra half cup of bread crumbs
-I used frozen green/red/yellow peppers from Kroger.  I defrosted them in the microwave, then squeezed out the excess water by hand.
-I used garlic from a prepackaged bottle of Spice World minced garlic instead of expensive fresh garlic.  Half a teaspoon of minced garlic is roughly equal to one clove of garlic.  (I use this bottled, minced garlic with much success in just about everything that calls for fresh garlic.)
-I mashed the beans with a potato masher instead of a fork.  It worked very well.
-I lightly coated a foil-covered cookie sheet with sprayable, canned vegetable oil.

All of this worked out very well.  The fact that this recipe is quite inexpensive only makes it that much better, if you ask me.  I made the recommended four patties per can of black beans, and the patties were pretty big.  My fiance and I both think that the patties could have been a little bit smaller, though, so next time I will probably make five patties per can of beans instead of four.

I will definitely make these again in the future.

region:

country:

text:
All the hype is warranted. I won't be buying anymore frozen veggie burgers.
This is a great recipe-I really didnt change too much.
I doubled the recipe. I drained two cans of black beans in a colander, then patted then dry with a paper towel, then mashed them with a fork.
I diced an onion, 3 garlic cloves, 1/2 green &1/2 yellow pepper. I had some mushrooms and roasted red peppers I threw in, too. I doubled the chili powder and cumin, but kept the chili oil paste at 1 T. I used 3 small eggs. 
I dont have a food processor, so I put all the diced veggies in first and choped them, then added the eggs and mashed black beans. I dumped it all back into the bowl, added the spices and breadcrumbs (Italian Seasoned) and mixed it up. You may need to add a little more crumbs, depending on consistancy(how big your eggs will make a consistancy difference)

I just fried one up in an olive oil sprayed pan and it was awesome!!
Thanks for the great, healthy recipe!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVED LOVED LOVED the taste of this recipe! I made it last night and tweaked the ingredients and recipe
1. I added brown rice like others had recommended 
2. because my family has a spicier palate I decided to nix the bell peppers and add hot chili peppers, 
3. I finely chopped the garlic and onions and mixed everything by hand 
4. To make it healthier I added 2 egg whites instead of a whole egg as the recipe called for 
5. I added wayy more bread crumbs 
6. before I froze my batch I dipped each patty into an egg white then bread crumbs mixed with taco seasoning 
In all GoodStuff!

I have to tell you I have never put in a review before but couldn't let this go.  I tried a black bean burger when out one day at a local resturant and just had to look it up here.  I was suprised to only find 2 recipes to choose from.  I tried yours and loved everything about it.  I did use 2 eggs and extra bread crumbs. I also pulled out my hamburger press and then I froze them before cooking. They still fell apart but what does that matter? Neatness isn't everything....
I put them on a wheat roll with black/corn salsa GREAT!!! The hamburger press that was in the closet for years is now out for good and I will be making this recipe often.  thanks

text:
This is a very good recipe. I enjoyed making these, they weren't hard at all, and I'm not even very good at cooking! Anyway, the only changes I made were to add more bread crumbs (I used seasoned bread crumbs also) and just eyeball to see how the consistency changed. Another thing, if you aren't a big fan of cumin ( like me) DO NOT ADD 1 TABLESPOON. I only used about 1/2 tbsp. and the cumin overwhelmed the rest of the ingredients. Next time I make these I'll only use about 1/2-1 tsp. Thanks again for a great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I  just made some of these (with a few substitutions) and ate one for lunch. Delicious! I had soaked and cooked a pound of kidney beans, so I tripled the recipe and used 5 cups of kidney beans. I did what one reviewer advised and drained/dried everything as much as possible. I used some cayenne instead of pepper sauce and added black pepper and fresh parsley (had some around, why not), and salt (since they weren't canned and needed it). I needed more bread crumbs like the same reviewer said, so I used 1/2 cup of cornmeal (it worked, but not particularly good enough to recommend). I made the patties big and baked them a few minutes longer. So good! I'ma keep playing with this recipe, thanks! Update: I froze the rest and they're really dry when reheated. Maybe it was the cornstarch.

text:
Simple to make and tastes very nice!  Substituted orange pepper for green (that's all I had) and used 1/2 cup of brown rice in addition to a sprinkle of bread crumbs. Following other users I blended the pepper, onion, garlic together and threw in some green beans and a red chili (for an extra kick!) - blotted the mixture with a paper towel to absorb the extra juice.  Only change I will make next time is reduce the cumin - although I like it I found it a little overpowering in the burgers.

text:
My mom is a vegetarian, so I thought these would make the perfect the Mother's Day lunch.  They were quite a success.

I had a little trouble grilling them, so I ended up frying most in a non-stick pan.  I might try baking them next time, frying seemed to leave them very squishy in the middle.  I would also suggest serving on some thinly sliced sourdough instead of hamburger buns, since the patties are thin.  They would also be great in tortillas quesadilla style, or just taking the bean mixture and making a burrito out of it.  It is so tasty.  I got lots of compliments on the flavor.

Followed others advice and used 2 eggs, which made it too mushy to form into patties...so I added more bread crumbs and used a scoop to get them on the fry pan.  Once they cooked though, they were a good consistency. Better than the frozen ones, plus WAY cheaper and you know what's in them.  Will definitely make again...thanks!

I'm not a bit spicy food fan - these have the perfect kick with the chili powder).  My only complaint is that this was pretty dry.  I'm not sure how to change that...maybe fewer breadcrumbs?  Leave a bit of the black bean juice in the mixture?  I'll definitely experiment and be making these again!

country:
None
text:
I altered this by using celery, carrot, onion, garlic, and green pepper. I seasoned with garlic powder, cajun seasoning and all-purpose seasoning. I also used red taco sauce(Pace brand) instead of chili sauce. I did NOT use any egg b/c my boyfriend is a vegan. Refrigerated for about 1 hour then formed into patties. I baked at 375 for about 30 mins per side then broiled on high for 2-3 mins per side for extra crispiness. I had a little trouble turning them after the first 30 mins...it required 2 spatulas to keep them from falling apart but after that no problems with turning. Topped with fresh salsa...VERY TASTY!!!!

text:
These were good; we definitely liked them more than store bought veggie burgers.  I changed up the spices to fit my tastes:  1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes and 1/2 teaspoon tabasco.  I still found it very spicy, and will probably cut back further in the future.  I made this ahead of time and refrigerated for about 3 hours before making patties.  I added ~7 minutes to the baking time and they came out great.  I topped them with ketchup, but I think I'll follow the other reviewer's suggestion of avocado and sour cream next time.  Thanks for the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic base recipe, but you need to add to it. I added shiitake mushrooms, cilantro, 1/2 jalapeño and carrots. The most important thing I did was sauté on medium the veggies (mushrooms, onions, garlic bell pepper and the jalapeño) in olive oil and some black pepper for about 5 minutes. (Add the garlic last so it doesn’t burn.) Just a slight sauté brings out a crazy depth of flavor and is worth the extra few minutes. I did not add the carrot or cilantro or the saute, but I suppose you can.

I prepped the patty mixture ahead of time. Formed 4 meatballs shapes and put them in the refrigerator until I was ready to cook. Once on the pan I smashed into a Patty. I feel refrigerating helped it stick together better. I was able to make on a grill pan. Approx 8 min on high each side. I added this to a salad - Boston Bibb lettuce, red pepper, carrots , red cabbage, scallions. I also made a dressing with fresh juiced ginger (you can mince instead), soy sauce, Rice vinegar, olive oil, garlic.

userID:
10104548
Display Name:
cfaden

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was amazing! After reading the reviews about it being wet I decided to change a few things. I rinsed the beans and put them in the pressure cooker for 10 min.(to solve the lectin problem) along with a small splash of chicken broth. When they were done I drained them and pressed on them with a wad of paper towels. 
I grated the onion and squeezed out the water by hand and then again with a paper towel or you could use cheese cloth. I didn't use the peppers because I am allergic to them. I minced the garlic by hand. 
I used two eggs and I added my own mix of chili seasoning but only about a 1/2 tsp or so. 
When it was all mixed I fried them in a frying pan with EVOO. I experimented with one coated in bread crumbs and one without. Without was way better! They held together perfectly. I mixed some mayo with srirachi to dip in. 
Because of the extra pressure cooker step, considering time,  I will double this recipe so I can freeze them. Outstanding!
A few extra steps but it was well worth it

5

text:
These are super easy, and freeze well so I usually make a double batch.  I don't even bother sauteing the onions and peppers: I just mince them pretty finely.  If the mixture seems too wet, I add 1/4 cup cooked rice or quick oatmeal.   I add cumin and a bit of chili powder.   Top with sciracha mayo (2 tbsp sciracha to 1/2 cup mayo)   for pure yum!

This was like a high end burger you would have while sipping wine at a Napa Valley winery. This is the way we felt when we were eating them. They were delicious as written. I did strain excess water from the pepper-garlic-onion mixture and I added a bit more bread crumbs (as needed) to bring the right consistency and it worked great. I've made this dish twice and both times cooked them on the grill. The first time we didn't cook them for long enough so I suggest to follow the directions. The cooking time in this recipe is pretty accurate. Thank you for for a delicious and healthy burger recipe!

So so good! I will say, I puréed the peppers, onions, and garlic instead of just chopping up. It spread out the flavor well and mixed in with the beans perfectly. My burgers did need about ten extra minutes but i think that’s because i made them too thick rather than wider so I’d change that next time- i poked holes in them which evened out the cooking. Oh, and i did take advice from one of the other reviews and change 1/2 cup of bread crumbs to 3/4 cup which really helped with  Consistency. My husband loved them which is the biggest compliment the recipe could get.

I chop all the veg in the food processor and drain off some liquid. I rinse the beans as well. I also add some extra bread crumbs, freeze and grill from frozen. I'm pretty wimpy on the spice front all I leave out the chili from the recipe but add a squirt of sriracha. That's perfect for me. Better than store bought for sure!!

text:
I've made these twice so far for my mom, she has trouble stomaching meat these days, and she's gone crazy for them. Even I'm tempted to eat these bc they smell so good and I despise black bean lol

I add garlic and onion powder and pepper to the spices that go in (I don't have chili sauce) and I followed another reviewer's advice on freezing them. I do take some of the juices out of the veggies but that's bc mine were frozen and had extra moisture, haven't tried with fresh yet. I bake mine and put them on parchment paper to make flipping easier and add 5min to each side since they're frozen.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First timer making veggie burgers and I was happily surprised!  I read a few recipes and decided on this one.  I opted to lightly cook the onion, green pepper and garlic before adding to the recipe. I also added one baked sweet potato and a handful of chopped cilantro (both things I saw in other veggie burger recipes that I like the idea of).  To balance out the dryness I had to add a bit more bread crumbs.   I grilled on the bbq and they stayed together and were delicious!  A bit of sweetness from the sweet potato and texture from the mashed black beans.  Served with thinly sliced red onion, avocado and bbq sauce.  The bbq sauce is a MUST!!!  I will definitely make these again.

text:
I made these and I really liked it.  Instead of using breadcrumbs, I used rolled oats (1/2 cup).  I also added a carrot to the onion (I used red onion), green pepper and garlic.  After chopping them in my food processor I squeezed out as much water as I could (I used paper towels, but cheesecloth would work better).  I also sauteed some mushroom and added it.  I also added in 1/2 cooked brown rice.  To the seasonings I added salt, pepper, cilantro, garlic powder, and onion powder.   I found it easy to form the patties by using a 1/2 cup measuring cup and slightly pressing down ( with oiled palms) and got 5 patties of equal size.  I froze mine before cooking and it came out great.

5

2019-02-07T14:36:01.26

text:
The description is correct: I will never buy frozen BBburgers again! : ) I will make a batch and individually freeze the cooked burgers for work lunches. I used chopped red pepper, garlic, carrots, and cauliflower. I drained the water from the veggies best I could and also laid the rinsed beans out to dry for a while. But the burgers were still pretty wet. They cooked up okay. I think I'll try cooked rice instead of bread crumbs next time and see how that does. **Three garlic cloves was very strong. Next time I will use less (I'm not sure if this is because I chopped them rather than minced?). 
This is a great base recipe and I look forward to adding all sorts of veggies in with it. Maybe mushrooms, spinach, corn, etc.

text:
I have made these burgers about a dozen times now, and they are DELICIOUS. I first looked for the recipe when my daughter was a vegetarian. Even after she went back to eating meat, we continue to make these. They are way more flavorful than other veggie burgers. I’ve made them following the recipe to the T (baked), and I’ve also cooked them in a cast-iron skillet when I needed the oven for something else. Great both ways, though they keep from falling apart better in the skillet. Usually I follow the recipe, but I’ve also made them when I didn’t have any green pepper, and I’ve altered the spice levels for my kids. Everybody loves them, including my two year old. When she was even littler, I made little “meat” balls out of these for dipping. Those were great, too. This is really a fool-proof recipe, it’s SO YUMMY, it’s healthy, and it’s cheap. What more could you want? :)

text:
I made this for my vegetarian son, and he gave it a five star rating. He really likes the veggie burgers that I get at the grocery store, but he likes these even more. That’s fine by me because I figure the cost is about 1/3, and the burgers are larger. I followed the recipe exactly, and I didn’t have the wet burger problem that some of the reviewers have complained about.  I also put on a slice of real American cheese two minutes before taking them out of the oven. Two burgers with cheese and rolls is about 900 calories. Toast the rolls on a skillet with butter to add additional calories and flavor. If you have vegetarian kids, calories are good.

userID:
23865571
Display Name:
Osanchez96
isPro:
False

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Take the advice of others and dont forget to dry your beans after you rinse them and strain your veggies of excess liquid. I doubled this recipe and found that the amount of cumin called for per serving could be reduced to about 2/3 of a tbs and comes out just right. Cumin in these burgers are what provide the main flavor  component of this recipe. I also changed out the chilli powder for  chipotle chilli powder and green pepper for red pepper since that  was all I had in my kitchen (it added some sweetness to the recipe which helped balance the chilli powder and hot sauce). I added 1 tsp ground white pepper and 1/2 tsp of garlic and onion powder. Instead of bread crumbs I took about 1/2 package of town house crackers (you can use ritz crackets as well) and used a food processor to break it down to about a half a cup. I also added some corn to the mixture when bringing it all together. If its still too watery and sticky you can try adding more bread crumb. I simply took some wax paper and shaped out my patties. Stuck it in the freezer and cooked them from frozen.  Theres so many things you can add to improve the flavor of this recipe

text:
I've made this recipe twice - first time as written and it was good.  Second time I added a grated carrot, chopped parsley and more hot sauce - MOST IMPORTANTLY - I dredged the patties in flour and gently fried them in a little oil (I used coconut but olive or veg oil works too).  They look better, taste better and hold together better.  I make 8 burgers out of this recipe, use four and freeze four.  It works well.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5432018.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe and it was super easy to make! I substituted the full TBSP  of cumin for a TBSP of taco seasoning which has cumin in it plus other spices. To make it vegan, I used 1 TBSP of flaxseed mixed with 3 TBSP instead of the egg. I read from one review to use Ritz Crackers instead of bread crumbs so I went with the crackers. I rinsed my beans and blotted with paper towel. I also squeezed out the excess water from veggies. I pan fried with olive oil. They were perfect and didn't even come close to falling apart!!!  Next time I will add other ingredients like other reviews suggested, such as corn and maybe carrots to add texture to the inside.

text:
I made it vegan by replacing the egg with chia seeds. take 1 tbsp of chia seeds with hot water and  allow it to sit and gelatinize. Once you get to the recipe where  you're supposed to the egg, I took 1 tbsp of the gelatinized chia seeds and added it to the black bean mixture. It worked perfectly! Oh and I did drain my beans and the bell pepper and onion mixture, I highly recommend it.

text:
This recipe is to die for! For those that put the beans in the processor to mash up like me, it may be more loose than you want it. Once all ingredients are combined I just added more bread crumbs to make it less soupy and stick together. I added seasoning salt on top before baking. With 10 minutes left, I took some yellow onions and green apples and caramelized them in a skillet adding cinnamon. The burger turned out sooooo good!  To make it spicier add more hot sauce or spicy sauce that you prefer or even consider adding holepeños when pulsing the onion, bell pepper, and garlic. I hope you all enjoy the recipe as much as I do!

text:
This was my first attempt at making a black bean burger and I was pleasantly surprised!!! I did make some changes so that's why the 4 star review and not 5. Like some other reviewers stated, to keep the burgers from falling apart after rinsing and draining the beans, I dried them with a paper towel. Also after chopping the peppers, onions and garlic in the food processor I drained them on a paper towel as well. I had to add an additional 1/4 cup bread crumbs to hold it together. I used italian style panko bread crumbs.  For some variety, I substituted equal parts red and green pepper. Yummy!!!

Display Name:
Jules

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1527426.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually try to make a recipe how it’s written, but after reading reviews I did the following:  I used red bell pepper, I drained and rinsed the black beans, dried them with paper towels, and mashed them with my squiggly potato masher. I used oats in the food processor - 1/2 cup. I put the onions and bell pepper in the food processor and drained them well on paper towels.  I used about a half table spoon of cumin since most people said it was over powering. Everything else I did as written. I made 3 patties, refrigerated them for about 1/2 hour, then fried them in a pan with olive oil. They were never runny, formed into patties well and were great! I think I had too much bell pepper because that was the main flavor but they were really good. I salted and peppered them like regular hamburgers. I never had a veggie burger before but will definitely make these again.

*Updated - I had to take a star away. My husband fessed up that he was pretty lukewarm about this and doesn't especially want it again.

text:
I made a few changes based on others' recommendations. I increased the breadcrumbs (half panko and half seasoned breadcrumbs), the cumin, and added an extra egg. I also did what one reviewer said about drying off the beans first. I didn't have a bell pepper, so I cooked up a cup of mixed frozen veg (carrots, beans, and corn), drained and squeezed it out, and then added that to the food processor with the beans. I also added a good douse of Tony Chachere's Cajun seasoning, too, and they were very tasty! When summer comes, we will be trying these out on the grill. Glad I tried them!

This homemade Black Bean Veggie Burger was great!! I followed the ingredients and directions exactly. The only thing I did differently was rinse the black beans and drain on a cotton napkin for maybe an hour before mashing..Cooked in my cast iron pan with a little coconut oil. I didn’t have any problems with them falling apart as others have stated.Then served on onion buns with my homemade ketchup and a homemade dill spear. Yum!!

text:
I too had a hard time keeping this from crumbling apart, so I recommend adding a 2nd egg, and being sure to drain all water from beans and other ingredients before adding them.

I also substituted rolled oats for the bread crumbs—they're more nutritious and have more fiber. 

Finally, if you fry these in a pan or on a griddle, I recommend you add a few tablespoons of oil (e.g. olive oil) to keep them from sticking to the cooking surface.

text:
I made this recipe as directed, however I didn’t use the food processor to chop my veggies. I finely minced them up with my knife so I didn’t have to worry about draining the extra water from them, as many others have mentioned. After I mixed them all up, I put them into a bowl and divided them into four sections and refrigerated for 2-3 hours. They were very easy to form and the patties came out just like a hamburger. I will give these 5 stars!!!

text:
This was my first time making black bean burgers. I mostly, but didn't quite, follow the recipe exactly. I added finely diced mushrooms for texture and earthiness, and some parsley after mixing everything else together. I also used 1/4 cup rolled oats and 1/4 cup plus about 3 tablespoons of bread crumbs. I accidentally grabbed my Thai curry paste instead of Thai chili paste and it smelled funny prior to cooking but it blended right in and just added some good flavor.  If I'd used more diced mushroom and another 1/4 cup of bread crumbs, these could almost pass for beef burgers. They smell great and give a satisfying sizzle while they're cooking and get nice and brown and crispy on the outside. I had no problem with them falling apart. Thank you!

text:
So good! Recommend not overdoing the veggies in the food processor. While no one wants a huge chunk of onion or green pepper in a bite of a black bean burger, if the veggies are too pureed it gets a little watery and can make the patties mushier. However,  I kinda like/expect black bean burgers to be a bit mushy so they were still AMAZING. I made them for my family, and they LOVED them. Added a slice of provolone cheese two minutes before taking the patties out of the oven. Pairs great with sweet potato wedge fries.

text:
I found this dish very good and easy enough to make, but having read others' comments, I'd agree that I'd use less cumin by half, make sure to strain the veggies after they come from the food processor, and increase the bread crumbs from the original amount by about half.  I loved the versatility of this dish. It does serve as a burger with mustard, ketshup, and dill pickle, but it also makes a nice toping to a spinach salad.  I have yet to include it in an omlet, but I suspect it would work nicely there too.  I"ll make it again for sure.

text:
2017-11-23 - I made this as written, except that I omitted the bell peppers and cumin, and I cooked in a frying pan instead of baking/grilling.  These were okay.  With two cups of beans cooked from dry (and then rinsed and drained), these held together well in the pan.  The flavoring of Thai chili sauce and chili powder didn't seem to work well for the burger, but it wasn't terrible.  The texture of just mashed beans + breadcrumbs was far too smooth and mealy.  If I make these again, I think maybe I'd sauté the onion and garlic, or roast the garlic, and try different flavorings.  Instead of breadcrumbs, I might follow another review and use 1.5 cups quick oats.  (We ate these as part of garbage plates.)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-11-14T21:57:08.08
helpfulCount:
0

22745241

laura Leon

text:
These burgers are good but just way too spicy using the amounts listed. I love spicy food, but these made me cough they were so spicy. I did use hot sauce as opposed to chili sauce and that probably made a big difference. If you don't have chili sauce and are using hot sauce, use half the amount listed if you want a mildly spicy burger, and even less if you don't want a distinctly spicy flavor in your burgers.

text:
Super easy and can all be done right in food processor. I placed onion, red bell pepper and about five baby carrots in first. Then added beans and gave a few pulses. Added bread crumbs, eggs and seasonings.  I added onion powder instead if garlic and added a little salt. To shape, I placed a piece of seran wrap in bottom of a hamburger shaped container and then added 1/2 cup of mixture and pressed down. It pulled right out and wrapped up neatly and individually for freezer.  I doubled recipe and made 8 patties.

text:
Tried once, aweful.   Modified...excellent.   
2 cans black beans-rinsed and drained well
1/2 large red onion
1/2 red pepper
1 jalapeno
3 garlic cloves
1 c. Bread crumbs
1 egg
1 T. Cumin
1 t. Pepper
2 t. Hot pepper sauce
Followed instructions per recipe.
Made 8 patties.  Put on wax paper, froze.  Bagged for future use.  About 197 calories per patty.

text:
These were great. My 12 yo vegetarian daughter loved it, and she generally doesn't like veggie burgers. Her comment, "this is basically a bean burrito in a bun."  She wants me to make them again soon, so I know this will be a summer grill staple. 

A couple of things you need to know: 1. The mixture is too wet as written. I added about twice the amount of breadcrumbs (panko) and they were still soft, but worked well.  Second, it needed salt.

Fantastic! This burger is absolutely delicious. I reduced one star, though, because like others, I found the mixture a bit wet at first in spite of drying my beans with a paper towel after rinsing. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely wonderful flavor. Be sure to dry the beans a bit before mashing, and be careful not to take away all of the texture in the beans when mashing. There will be juice in food processor after creating the garlic, onion and green pepper mixture so drain that out a bit too. I added salt and a couple of tablespoons of toasted slivered almonds very lightly chopped and about 4 more tblsp bread crumbs. We made four and ate two one night and put other two in fridge for next night. To reheat I put them uncovered in microwave for about 44 seconds, the crisped up in medium high heat frying pan with a bit of olive oil. Just as good next day. We put red onion, pickles, avocado, tomato and lettuce on ours. Really tasty favorite (and I love a good hamburger, but this A GREAT alternative).

text:
There is not really anything unique about this recipe from dozens of of other bean burger recipes. I used freshly prepared beans, a mixture of black, small red, and pintos. It takes a lot more that the recommended amount of bread crumbs to dry it out enough to form a pattie. This might have been due to the freshly made beans. However, I both fried this and baked it. Both firmed up nicely.
Next time I will use fresh bread run through a food processor instead of bread crumbs. Should absorb more moisture and be a little less mealy. It might also be interesting to use Provencal-like seasonings like sage, thyme and rosemary for a different flavor.

text:
I mixed it up and baked one. Very good! Then I "improved" it for my taste, which I won't go into, because it turns into a different recipe. I know that makes some people crazy...! If you bake them in the oven, use parchment paper, rather than tin foil, to line the baking sheet. I found my first burger in two pieces - top and bottom - because it stuck to the foil so badly! ("Improvement" involves lots of sriracha sauce, few drops of Worcestershire sauce,  more breadcrumbs to offset the extra liquid, mushrooms, sun dried tomato bits and some small dice chayote for extra crunch, among other things. See? I told you it would be a different recipe!)
I really liked it as written though!

userID:
2200896
Display Name:
Jannabofanna
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
44
favoritesCount:
101
recipesCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/73371.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My attempt at making my own instead of buying at the store! I did read through some reviews and took note of changes. I made my own substitutions tailoring to WW points which came to 4 SP. I cut the cumin in half, added an ear of cooked corn on the cob and grated carrot for personal taste. I also added some smokey paprika, and I used quick oats that I blended down a little finer because that's what I had in the pantry. Prep was probably the biggest change I made as I was fearful of them being too wet and I also wanted a quicker cook time after freezing. After chopping the onion, red pepper and grated carrots I sprayed a baking dish with Pam and put them covered in the oven at 300 till they were tender. I took care of making sure the beans and onion mixture was strained and most of moisture was out. I also believe precooking the veggies drew quite a bit of moisture out. This was a very good recipe. Thanks!
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:
2017-03-11T02:20:33.643
helpfulCount:
0

text:
These burgers are absolutely stunning and I would recommend anyone to try them out. For spices I would try and taste and add what you like, I myself added salt and cayenne pepper. I also used red beans in stead of black ones.

However, since the recipe is quite heavy and full in itself in terms of flavor, I countered it with a pinch of lemon juice. Not a lot but just to balance the fullness with a little bit of freshness. 

TLDR; I'd add more spices and some lemon juice to add some freshness.

text:
My omnivore husband loves these. I use rolled oats instead of breadcrumbs and add about 2 tbs more than a half cup which helps the burgers hold together better. I also use a food processor to combine ingredients, putting the beans in last and just pulsing a few times so the mixture doesn’t get too mushy. We like them well done. Serve with sliced tomato and avocado, with sweet potato fries and coleslaw on the side. So much better than store-bought!

I made this as suggested by others to reduce sogginess of burgers.  Paper towel drained everything to remove moisture, dried out beans before mashing, froze them before cooking,  and doubled breadcrumbs..They still came out mushy, but the flavor was very good.

I selected this recipe because I would like to cut more meat from my diet. I followed the recipe except I substituted oatmeal for bread crumbs. I baked the patties and they held together well, but I suspect they would fall apart if I had tried to grill them. Other reviews suggest adding an additional egg or squeezing out extra liquid from the chopped veggies, but I don't think that's necessary if your plan to bake. I liked the ratio of spices, but next time I'll add salt. I'll also experiment with different spices and add other types of veggies.

As mentioned in reviews, I rinsed and dried the beans and then I used  the same pastry cloth to dry the finely chopped onion and green pepper. The flavor wasn't bad. I agree they don't turn out hot at all (that's good), however, I think a little liquid smoke would've improved the flavor. A big help would be to make sure the burgers are thin! I grilled them with a typical one inch thickness and pressed down the center and they turned out pasty in the middle.  Sorry, but the quantity of work (utensils and drying) combined with the texture didn't make this recipe worth it.

text:
First I have to say I was BLOWN away with the amount of flavor and how great these were. I didn’t miss eating a beef patty. The consistency wasn’t bad not too mushy and not to solid perfect. I was so excited to share these with my coworkers. I will have to be HONEST “THIS WAS MY FIRST EVER BLACK BEAN BURGER” and have been wanting to order one for some time now. I am more than HAPPY that I made this myself because I do not think anything will compare to these.  
I did follow other reviewer’s suggestion when it came to freeze them night before and to strain the bell pepper and onion mixture. 
1.	I did rinse and strain the black beans really well and let sit for a little. 
2.	The bell pepper and onion finely chopped in a ninja was more of a slush mixture. I definitely needed to strain the mixture really well but using a mesh strainer and hand before adding to the black mixture smash. This took about 10 to 20 minutes to get a lot of the liquid out. 
3.	Egg mixture- I didn’t have all the spices that was suggested. Instead of the chili powder and cumin I used: paprika, oregano and cayenne pepper. I aslo added black pepper and garlic salt (these I eyeballed the measurement). I used the Asian hot sauce with the green lid (Sambal Oelek, ground fresh chili paste)
4. I used Ritz crackers rather than bread crumbs. 
5.	I freezed them the night before 
6.	Baked at 350 degrees on both sides for 10 minutes each.

Display Name:
Mike Couch
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3940575.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a 5/5 with some changes, here's what I did. I used 2 cans of beans, 2 aneheim peppers, 1/2 onion, 1 carrot, cilantro, 5 garlic cloves, 3 egg yolks, breadcrumbs to texture, spices(cayenne, cumin, and chili powder), salt, and pepper. Blend the vegetables and strain out the excess fluid. Mash the black beans in a bowl. Beat the egg yolks with the spices. Add all ingredients together and add breadcrumbs until the mixture can be formed into patties that hold their shape. I cooked on a cast iron skillet, get the skillet medium-high with a splash of oil and try to get a crust on the burgers. Don't be afraid of over-cooking these things, they have plenty of moisture in them. Makes 8 patties, freeze before cooking for later use.

Made this last night and loved it! I followed the ingredients as written but used less cumin as it is not my fav spice. It had a nice kick to it, not overwhelming, just enough spice to give it some flavor. To keep the patties from being too watery, I dried the beans and chopped veggies on paper towels for a few minutes before mixing and let the mixture sit in the fridge for an hour before forming the patties. The burgers held together nicely. Topped it with guacamole, jalapeños, lettuce and tomato. Definitely will make this again!

text:
I made some adjustments based off other reviews and my kids preference. First I doubled the recipe. Used red pepper instead of green and vidalian onion. I used about two shakes of cayenne pepper and 2 tsp sweet chili sauce. I also added about 3/4 can creamed corn. I pulsed the pepper and onions first and then added the black beans, garlic (used heaping spoons) and spices. I then pulses that a few times and put the mixture in a big bowl where I added 1 1/4c Panko crumbs and about another 1/4c Italian (as I ran out of Panko and it still needed more) and then one egg. Mixed with my hands and then used Saran Wrap and a burger press to make the burger patties. I got 7 large burger patties that I then froze in their Saran Wrap.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-07-26T03:58:59.243

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe. Easy to put together. I cooked dry beans in a slow cooker and then weighed out 16 ounces of cooked beans for this recipe.  I highly recommend purchasing a kitchen scale--especially for weighing flour.

I pretty much followed this recipe exactly, except per comments, I only put 1 teaspoon each of cumin and chili powder.

I put the processed garlic, bell pepper, and onion onto a paper towel in a strainer, and then I picked up the paper towel and squeezed all the moisture out of the vegetables.

I used a potato masher to mash the beans.

I used the same amount of egg and breadcrumbs as the recipe indicates and the mixture came together just fine. I was able to form perfect burgers.

I baked the burgers, and they were yummy. We will be making these again. Plus it is only 1/2 the cost of buying store bought veggie burgers.

userID:

Display Name:
Paulina Pelaez

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3209406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the suggestions of draining and drying the black beans. I also got a headstart in mashing them with my Vitamix first, and finished it off with a fork. 

I dislike raw onion so whenever I make meatloaf or burgers I sweat my onions/garlic to get some of the water out. With these I knew I HAD to because everyone complained about them being crumbly because they probably had too much moisture (from the onions). I didn't have green bell pepper so I just omitted it, I used ancho chilli powder, 1/2 tsp of cumin (not a huge fan of cumin), and 1/2 tsp of cayenne pepper. I used the recommended amount of breadcrumbs (panko) because panko does tend to absorb a lot of water.

I made them in the oven 10 minutes on one side, and about 13 minutes on the other so they would dry out a little more. I flipped them with no problems. I had mine in a salad (all 4 of them, I hadn't had breakfast!) and they held together really well, even through quartering them. I smeared some laughing cow cheese wedges (x2) and some guac on top of them before I quartered them.

I will be making these again for when I don't feel like putting too much effort into lunch/dinner.

text:
I really love these veggie burgers but made a few modifications to the recipe.  While preparing I throughly strained (after rinsing) the black beans and also the onion, green pepper and garlic which created a fair amount of liquid in the food processor.  I added some extra bread crumbs, pinch of salt, and cracked pepper as well.
Instead of 4 large burgers I made the burgers a bit smaller  and cooked them in a little olive oil on the stove. The first time I made these according to the recipe they took forever baking  and still could have cooked more.  I have not tried them on the grill.
This is my go to recipe!

text:
Great foundation recipe, Like others I made tweaks, Doubled the recipe cut the cumin (used the T for the double batch), added 2t of Worcestershire sauce and about 3/4 to 1 Cup of baby carrots added to the processor. Took the food processor mixture and cooked it for about 5 min to soften the veggies and drained some of the water that was released. It should also be noted that I REALLY processed the onion and green pepper, a few extra bread crumbs and TA DAAAA!! My 15 yr old Black Bean Burger Connoisseur was extremely pleased.

I made these for my vegetarian daughter in law and ended up enjoying them as much as her. After reading reviews I decided to add some rice and mushrooms to the mix and cutting a bit of the cumin. None
text:
Brilliant burgers. I highly suggest topping with feta, tzatziki sauce, and some onion.

With any black bean burger, you'll want to remove as much  moisture from the beans and veggies as possible for the patties to hold together. Extra bread crumbs help.

I doubled the recipe and froze the extras. 15 minutes per side in a 375 degree oven on a greased pan will cook them perfectly from frozen.

text:
I followed other reviews and cut down the cumin.  I added 1 tsp. cumin, which I would think is what was meant to be, instead of 1 tbs, and the cumin was still very noticeable.  I didn't read the reviews until after I had added the onion, garlic, and bell pepper.  Next time I will definitely try draining out their juice.  I did add a half zucchini and half carrot grated and also added more bread crumbs to try and mitigate the juice.  I like the flavor of these but they did turn out too mushy for my families liking.   I think draining the juice will make these perfect next time.  This recipe definitely has potential.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2938271.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used the suggestions to make it less watery (like rinsing beans and squeezing water out of pepper mixture through a fine mesh strainer).Then I doubled the  recipe to freeze more for later. I also used 1.5 cups of oatmeal that I processed in a food processer in place of the breadcrumbs (3/4 c if not doubling recipe). I processed the oatmeal before I processed the pepper mix since it was dry and I did not want to get the oatmeal wet and clumpy with the moisture.  I added the ingredients together as noted and formed patties and grilled them. They held together perfectly. When they finished cooking, I let them sit until cool enough to handle and cut them in strips. We made burrito wraps with soft whole wheat tortillas and all our favorite fixings (sour cream, guac., salsa, cheese, lettuce, etc). It will definitely be a regular part my menu! The only thing I would change is adding salt which it needed badly. Oh and I sneaked pepper in which my kids HATE by using a red pepper (green was a dead giveaway). They thought it was tomatoes and loved every bite and asked for seconds!??

i really was truly impressed with these burgers. It was my first time substituting black bean for meat in my hope of becoming vegetarian.  Had I known I could've had such a fine burger years ago, I would've turned my back on meat years ago.  Flavorful, held together like a burger, including consistency. Hey, with all recipes you're gonna have to tweak it to make it right for you.  Thank you.  Oh yeah, one thing i did that folks may find useful - I used y garlic press on the onion as well, got rid of all excess onion fluid and it made it into a pleasant paste easy to mash and mix with the other ingrediants.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are terrific. I added a dice of carrot and mushrooms to the onion, red and yellow mini-peppers and garlic, and sautéed them first, then pressed the heck out of the cooked mixture through a sieve after pulse-processing. I wiped out the hot skillet I had used for the sauté and shook the rinsed and towel-dried beans around in the cooling pan for a few minutes, then mashed the beans in that skillet with a metal potato masher. With all this, I only needed 1/2 a cup of the breadcrumbs. I reduced the cumin as everyone seems to suggest, and thought the seasoning was perfect.

Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!! I can not rave enough about this recipe! I've been a vegetarian for about 7 years now and this is the "burger" I've been looking for. The flavor was on point, and the texture was perfect!! While I did find it slightly crumbly this really wasn't an issue for me.  In addition to being a fantastic recipe, I found that they froze really well which is a major plus for a full time student/full time worker! I can't believe I was spending $4 for four frozen processed veggie burgers. When I could make these for a little over $1.35! 
Again I say THANK YOU!!

region:

country:
None
text:
I used 1 can black beans, 1 small yellow bell pepper, 1/4 a white onion, 2 Tablespoons minced garlic, 1 egg, a pinch of chili powder, a pinch of cumin, 4 tablespoons BBQ sauce, 1 Tablespoon yellow mustard, 1 tablespoon ketchup, and pinch of salt. I blended those all together and then folded in a cup of crushed crackers. Next, I baked them for ten minutes on both sides. They were amazing! My husband gave me a high five.

text:
Made this for dinner today.  Took other reviewer recommendations on the use of 2 eggs instead of 1.  Used quick rolled oats to sub for the bread crumbs and added 1/2 cup TVP (textured vegan protein)  Final results turned out well, wasn't wet at all.  Didn't use the oven or grill for this first time trial.  I have access to a hot air convection cooker, gave the exterior of the veggie burger nice a crunch.  I skipped the bell pepper since it triggers my gout.  Will likely sub water chestnuts in for the bell pepper next time for some extra crunch :)  Will def make again.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you're hesitant about veggie burgers, I really suggest you give black bean ones a try. Probably one of the tastiest and still so healthy recipes I've made ever.

This recipe is a good base,  but definitely one of those recipes where you should adjust according to your tastes. I really don't like bell peppers, so I left them out. 

However, I did add finely diced carrots, celery, and mushrooms. Not much of a hot sauce fan, but I usually add heat using either crushed red pepper or cayenne pepper. Now that I'm writing this, I've realized I actually forgot to add the chili powder, but the burgers were still great.

1/2 cup of bread crumbs is probably all right, but I usually add a little more. I cut down the spices to about 1 tsp or 1.5 tsp each for chili powder/cumin.

Instead of grilling or baking, I pan fry these patties on the stove top with some oil, about 3-4 minutes per side on medium high heat.

text:
Great basic, vegetarian patty recipe!
Moist and savory with the following changes:
Oatmeal instead of bread crumbs
1/2 cup of shredded carrots instead of bell pepper
Chicken broth instead of water for quinoa
Baked at 400 degrees for 30 minutes 

Next Time i will use less garlic (mine was strangely strong) and grease my baking pan (serious sticking went on!) I will also try adding some nutritional yeast...

I agree with other reviews that this is a good base recipe where you can play with the spices and vegetables that go in!!

These were much better than many veggie burgers I have had. I used garbanzo beans instead of black beans and it worked just as well. I also added a little more hot sauce an cumin as a replacement for chili powder. I also used blended, whole wheat bread for bread crumbs and it worked just as well (you will need a little more than 1/2 a cup though). It was a little wet and took about 30 minutes to bake in a oven but I think that was because i used garbanzo beans instead of black beans. But other than that, very flavorful!

text:
The recipe as is, seems too wet. This is only my 2nd time making BB burgers, but based on my 1st attempt - consistency is key! I combined different reviewers' advice to get the mixture bulkier & drier.  Used closer to 3/4 c. bread crumbs, about 1/4 c. cooked quinoa (it was in my fridge), some extra zucchini & squash shreds (maybe a 1/4 c.). All of these additions got the mixture to a better bulkiness. It formed nice patties that did well in the oven. Haven't eaten any yet though!  Fingers crossed.

userID:
16603021
Display Name:
Linda Buckmaster
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2692639.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this. The overall flavour is nice, but you have to like cumin, and not everyone does.  

This recipe was obviously not tested, because if it had been, the amount of breadcrumbs would have been increased, as well as the addition of some salt.

I doubled the recipe so that I could freeze some burgers for future use, and added 1 cup of breadcrumbs.  It was way too wet to make patties.  I ended up adding about 2 more cups of breadcrumbs to a double batch; for a total of about 3 cups.  I just let the food processor run and kept pouring in breadcrumbs until it had the right consistency to form patties.

They are very bland because there is no salt in the recipe. Luckily I only cooked up 2 patties before realizing that it was screaming out for salt.

I would make it again, with the adjustments I made.  But the recipe as is, is terribly written, and obviously not tested.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-10-24T05:52:21.073

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2613233.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this.  

There are a lot of suggestions on how to make this work, so here's mine, which is super simple.

I did dry out the beans a bit but forgot to do so with the vegetables.

Otherwise, I just dumped everything in the bowl, as directed, except that I used gluten-free oatmeal in lieu of bread crumbs.

Then I whacked at it with my 'zing-zinger' - my immersion blender.  As another reviewer suggested I then let it sit - I put it in the fridge for a few hours.

I greased my hands just a bit, they made into patties beautifully, baked them as directed - fantastic.  Easy as could be and I only used one bowl and a baking sheet.  No need to any other gymnastics in my kitchen.

Enjoy!  Thanks for the great recipe!!

This recipe is lovely. I doubled the recipe. Rinsed my seasoned canned beans & pulsed them in a food processor. I don't like to taste partial beans in my bean parties. I didn't have to dry them. I added everything as listed but left out the hot sauce...for my kids :) They held great. I baked them during the day. Put them in the fridge & juts heated them in the oven quickly. They are easy to make, easy to bake, easy to re-heat & easy to eat :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My vegetarian daughter loves these. I changed things up a bit by using (ground) oatmeal instead of breadcrumbs, and by adding more shredded veggies (zucchini or anything else I might have in the fridge).  I also added a little more spices and some Worcestershire sauce. I used the posted tip to freeze and then cook - they definitely hold up much better that way. When grilling, definitely put on a piece of (lightly oiled) tin foil. We did make them once in a pan and they turned out great that way - easier to get a sear on them. Last time I made the recipe, I doubled it and froze a bunch for future use. My daughter (the vegetarian) requests these often, and likes them better than any store-bought veggie burger. BUT you must like the flavor of beans to enjoy these. Sounds obvious but the bean flavor is not masked.

text:
My boys declared, "This is the best meal ever!" I would say that's success for a 10 and  8 year old.

Some alterations I made to the recipe: 1) I added 1/2 tsp of salt. 2) Sautee minced onions (the food processor beats onions into a pulp... I won't use it) and celery in olive oil, then add minced garlic in the last 30 seconds of the sautee. 3) Exclude peppers. 4) I did use the food processor to make bread crumbs from two slices of sandwich bread. 5) I excluded the thai chili. Overkill. 6) After baking the patties, I sauteed them in olive oil to get a nice crust, then topped them with cheese. Yum!

text:
I absolutely loved this black bean burger! I thought the flavors came together wonderfully. We had some last night for dinner and the left overs for lunch today and they are even yummier! I omitted the cumin and Chili sauce for fear of my picky 5 year old not liking it, but everything else I did the same. I took advice from other reviewers and made sure to strain everything and squeezed between paper towels. Seemed like a lot of work because I was pressed for time but it was all worth it in the end. I made 5 burgers instead of 4 because my buns were a bit on the small size. I will probably be making these weekly as they are an easy lunch to prep the next day. My son was so happy he didn't have to eat meat (not a huge fan of beef) and enjoyed his black bean burger even though he always fusses about eating beans! I love beans, and do not eat meat so this recipe gets a 4.5 rating from me! The only reason I cannot give it 5 stars is because my meat loving husband said they were only okay. I have been trying to find substitutions so he can cut back on his meat but unfortunately this recipe will not work for him. Perhaps because it is not as hearty as a beef burger? Regardless I will continue making this for my son and myself. Thank you so much for sharing this wonderful recipe!

text:
I found the reviews very helpful (straining to remove excess moisture, use 2 eggs instead of one, substituted half of bread crumbs for crackers).  My one remaining question was the size of the patties.  Recipe stated 4 servings but they were huge!  Recommend smaller patties to fit on buns and firm up the insides a bit more.  Crisping them up in a frying pan (after baking in the oven) with a little oil adds to the texture.  Also added some carrots and peas to increase veggies. Just processed them with the other ingredients. Nice flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Must try it with Garlic Aioli recipe found on this site! Yummy!!  Like suggestions given, I use more bread crumbs (maybe 3/4 cup) & add more salt.  I use Pampered Chef's Mix n Chop to mash beans-saves soo much time! Also, use cheesecloth (or reusable, mesh turkey stuffing bag, found at Wal Mart in kitchenware for under $1) to strain all juice from veggies in seconds. In fact, dries out & holds together so well, that I'm able to add a small spread of butter to each burger for added flavor after flipping on George Foreman grill.  Oh, and out of habit, I always stick in freezer for a bit before grilling or even many days ahead.  They never fall apart on me.  I serve with pepper jack cheese and fresh-cut veggies...and don't forget the secret weapon-Garlic Aioli!! Served mine on grilled focaccia bread...delish!!

text:
My 3 star rating is from the original recipe, 5 stars with adjustments suggested by others and a few done by myself. You have to strain the pepper mixture(added serrano pepper for more heat, I looove spicy food), add 1 cup of breadcrumbs and 2 eggs to the patties. I added the spices mentioned along with salt,pepper,serendipity,dried oregano, and cayenne. I was going for a which wich type sandwich but instead made it into a salad bowl. Like the previous poster I would freeze then grill, baking didn't workout too well for me but the patty will still awesome, and I froze the remainder. In the salad bowl, I toasted some sourdough bread and chopped it up, spinach, diced tomato, sautéed mushrooms w/ salt&pepper,avocado,parmesan blend cheese,& sliced black olives... I would recommend it more in a sandwich form w/ toasted french bread.

Switching out the crumbs for brown rice might do the trick. The garlic flavor was nice and strong. I had no problem with them falling apart.

userID:
13308801
Display Name:
Lil BBQ'n Bro
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
246
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great for inspiration, but needs a little coaxing to make them come out great. I used the full amount of bread crumbs (I used panko) because that's what I had in hand. I also added a little oats for an extra binder like some of the reviews said. I only used one egg becuae the extra oats helped hold them together perfectly. When I processed the onions, bellpepper, and garlic I added a few sliced jalapeños for an extra kick. It came out just a tad of the spicy side because I also used tobasco sauce. Next time I make them I will use a different hot sauce, most likely siracha, and add fewer jalapeños. Make sure to dry the beans on a paper towel until all of the moisture is gone, and they are completely dry. When I was finished processing the veg I put them in a fine mesh strainer and shook them until a lot of the liquid was out. Put a paper towel below and you will see how much liquid comes out! It takes a little longer, but is well worth the wait. I also added a pitch of garlic powder, parsley, and salt and pepper to taste! The cumin flavor is a little strong so maybe 3/4 of a tablespoon will work better next time. These are definitely better than store bought frozen veggie burgers, and are very inexpensive! I will make these again and make a bigger batch to freeze for a quick, healthy, and easy meal! Thanks for the recipe!

As a former carnivore gone pescitarian, I've been craving a hamburger but the store brought veggie burgers taste like cardboard so I wasn't expecting much when I made this for dinner tonight. I absolutely LOVED it! I didn't have green pepper so I only used onion and fresh garlic (I don't have a food processor so did a fine chop with my knife) and added a sprinkle of Tony Chachere's. If you are having trouble getting the ingredients to bind, try adding a little oatmeal along with the bread crumbs.

text:
5 stars for a delicious no-meat burger and for ease of preparation & cooking.  Made these for a burger-burn w/some vegitarian guests attending.  The non-meateaters enjoyed these & said these were much better than the store bought brands. I (a lover of a good meat burger) wound up eating one of these burgers instead of a meat burger - grilled with green chile and cheese on top :). Delicious.  As suggested by other reviewers, it is necessary to drain the beans very well and not mix the pepper & onion mixture in if its too wet.  You will need to drain some moisture off as needed. You can easily add more moisture if needed - just enough to "feel" the pattie texture will hold together when cooked & flipped over while cooking.

text:
This has become our go-to veggie burger recipe and we typically make it at least once a week! I like to add canned mushrooms, drained well and chopped, for a little extra flavor. They will hold together fine as long as you drain everything very thoroughly before mixing, and you can add some extra breadcrumbs if you're still having trouble. Delicious with some cheese melted on top. One of my most-used recipes.

text:
This is probably the best veggie burger recipe I have ever tried.  All the ingredients are staples in my pantry, and this is a much better route than a store bought, frozen burger.  The only changes I made were as follows:

I added: 
--2 Thai chilis instead of the chili powder
--Soy Chorizo from Trader Joes to add a little extra dimension and flavor to the recipe
--I doubled the garlic,because I believe there is no such thing as too much garlic.

This recipe also freezes really well (you don't compromise the texture or flavor) in case you've made more than you can eat.

text:
I made these for my daughter over Labor Day weekend. She thought these were very good and liked them. I followed suggestions made by other cooks. I added more bread crumbs, drained, rinsed and patted dry the beans, as well as drained the veggies and squeezed them dry before adding them to the bean mixture. I thought the spices were just right but maybe the next time I will add S/P too. I grilled them on foil on a charcoal grill and they did hold together nicely. I got about five thin patties. The next time I might make them thicker. I did freeze them first before grilling and that worked out just fine. I would make them again.

Display Name:
Alanna

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2707298.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe as written, and it was my first time making any kind of veggie burger. To be open-minded, you really need to disregard your experiences with out-of-the-box products that have more complex texture, such as a well-shaped patty with a slight crunch on the outside. This recipe wasn't intended for that. The flavor reminded me of my homemade black bean soup, which I make by following the recipe on the back on the Bush's can. Ingredients are similar. I used the grating disc on my food processor to handle the pepper and onion, and used a garlic press for the garlic. I tried to avoid having large chunks of any particular ingredient. This worked well. Also, I continued adding bread crumbs (panko was all I had on hand) until the mixture seemed appropriate for shaping patties. I probably ended up with twice the recommended amount. During cooking, the patties were mushy, but surprisingly they didn't fall apart when I flipped them. I cooked them longer than recommended until the patties were golden on top. They were definitely worth making again, although next time I might try skillet cooking them in a little butter to see if this adds some richness to the flavor. It needs a little something more, but I haven't figured out what yet.

text:
Made this tonight and it was a hit. My husband and I really enjoyed them and we are not vegetarians. We followed the recipe as above, but let the beans dry after rinsing them and dabbed the green pepper and onion mixture with paper towels to gather the extra liquid. Even though there is chili powder and hot sauce added it is not a "heated" amount. I also do not have a food processor and used my Pampered Chef chopper and it still blended as it should. I also took the advice from one of the reviews and mashed the beans with a flat object versus a fork. This a recipe that we will definitely be eating again.

text:
This is a really good black bean burger recipe!  I almost completely followed the recipe as written, with just the tiniest of tweaks.  I added a little more hot sauce because we like everything a little more spicy, and instead of adding more breadcrumbs like a couple of reviewers suggested, I added a half cup or so of cooked bulgar.  The burgers held together really well when I cooked on a skillet w/ a little oil spray, and the bulgar up-ed the protein even more. Since the mixture contained raw egg, I made a tiny "test burger" in the pan before cooking off the whole batch to check the seasoning- definately add salt if you aren't on a sodium restricted diet!

Delish! I have to admit, my first try of this recipe was using modifications but I don't think they are significant to the overall recipe. I love chipolte black bean burgers but am intolerant of dairy, egg yolks & yeast (at least 1 of which all processed foods seem to contain) so this recipe is a godsend for me. userID:
4173483
Display Name:
michelisima
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's easy to adapt this to a vegan, gluten-free diet. The egg and bread crumbs can be replaced with just over half a cup of grain mix (I used a mix of oats, brown rice, soybeans, millet and sorghum, but any of these on their own would probably do) and a splash of unflavored rice or soy milk. I like making them much smaller and serving them as vegetarian party food with various dips and grilled plantains on the side. A barbecued version would probably work great!

The basic recipe is delightfully easy and I didn't experience the problem that so many reviewers commented on of the burgers falling apart, possibly because I didn't use a food processor. Automation can make it too easy to cross the boundary between chopping and liquification, especially if you're using anything from a tin. I've certainly found that when making falafel - which uses comparable ingredients - so I stayed away from the machine from the outset. It's more work, but (at least for me) has more predictable results and looks prettier!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-12-15T17:47:59.987
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
10520577
Display Name:
suhan93
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am a vegetarian and Im always looking for new recipes with beans and these burgers are awesome. I always twist recipes and for this one I used red pepper instead of green, added more garlic, and used chipotle instead of chili sauce for the added kick. I put them on parchment and in the freezer for a little bit then rubbed olive oil on them and grilled them on the barbecue and they were delicious. 
Definetely a recipe to make again and again. My brother and my dad who are NON vegetarian had them and said "I gotta hand it to ya these are good." and these are people who swear by meat burgers LOL. 
NOTE: I did what a girl had mentioned in the reviews and doubled the egg amount and breadcrumbs as well as straining the pepper/onion/garlic mixture and it was perfect. 5 stars.
