text:
This one is a keeper. Nice flavor. Here is what I did different to keep the burgers from falling apart. I used used Town House crackers instead of the bread crumbs and I doubled the amount. I hand chopped the peppers, onions, and garlic and I also added fresh cilantro.  I formed the patties on a tin foil lined cookie sheet and froze before cooking. Cooked on a cast iron skillet with a small amount of canola oil. Cook until brown flip once and brown the other side. Maybe 7 minutes each side. Very delicious.

text:
I was leery of using canned beans, since so many reviews said it was more like batter than moldable dough.  I soaked my own beans, and cooked them until they were al dente.  Then I processed them in a meat grinder.  They came out fluffy and easily conformed to patties when used in this recipe.  I added an extra egg and an extra 1/4 c. bread crumbs, probably because I used more beans. I ended up with a mix that felt like meatloaf.  I baked them, and they were great!

Made these tonight for the first time. I used instant oats as suggested by others, along with 2 eggs. 

Overall, they were tolerable but next time I'll bake them. A little mushy on the inside, yet crisp on the outside.

I will try it again and perhaps try a few tweaks in the recipe to suit my tastes. 

I really want these to work out. I didn't have trouble making them stick together. I refrigerated the mix for an hour before cooking them. I plopped the mix on to a non-stick surface and pressed them into burgers with no troubles at all.

text:
Just made these burgers. The only changes I made were to add an extra quarter cup of bread crumbs, I used a yellow bell pepper instead, and I added a half a jalapeno pepper. I used my food processor to chop all the ingredients first, then mixed them and shaped them. I placed them on a foiled try and froze them for about an hour. I used a grill pan with a little Smart Balance spray to cook one up and it was YUM!!! I'm keeping the rest frozen for a quick lunch/dinner. They are a bit soft but it doesn't even matter because they're so tasty and healthy!

These are very very good!  I followed the recipe almost exactly except I probably used more breadcrumbs than called for (I didn't measure, just mixed them in until I liked the consistency.  I baked a few and fried a couple in a small amount of canola oil so I could decide which way I preferred.  I really couldn't decide between the fried and the baked, they were both excellent so in the future I will probably bake to keep them as healthy as possible.  I didn't eat them as burgers but made a small salad with lettuce, tomato, and avocado and added a little dressing and put the patty on top with some cheese.  An excellent light but filling dinner!  I gave it 4 stars only because I would have preferred a little more kick and a little less cumin.

text:
I love this recipe, It rocks and is so simple. My sister in law is a very picky eater; I convinced her to try one, and she asked for seconds. I call them 'chilli sandwiches' rather than veggie burger. For some reason this makes people more receptive of them 

I use off brand ritz crackers for bread crumbs, and I cook the black beans, rather than using canned. I triple the recipe every time I make it. The cost per serving is roughly 0.32 cents per sandwich, including a loaf of bread! I generally bake mine and eat them at least once a week; if not more!

text:
These had a great flavor but next time I will grill them or maybe try pan-frying them--that is strictly preference because I don't like the veggie burgers that you buy in the store due to a lack of texture.  If you are used to those then these are awesome.  I added just a little extra panko crumbs to ensure that they didn't fall apart.  I baked them for twelve minutes on one side and eight on the other hoping that they would firm up before the flip and they did great.  I also made 8 small patties instead of four, again to help keep them together.  Yum! UPDATE: I originally rated this 4 stars since I intended to change some things next time, however, my very meat-eating husband's curiosity got the better of him and he tried a tiny bite when I wasn't looking.  He said he was amazed at how good these are.  If this recipe gets him to eat a veggie burger then it deserves 5 stars and more.

text:
I have never had a black bean patty before, so I really have nothing to base this recipe on BUT these taste amazing! I made them for a big barbeque because my friend couldn't eat meat (lent). She was so happy I thought of her but even more so when she tasted them. She raved about the flavor! One thing that was different when i made them was that I used black beans that I had boiled myself. Maybe that was the difference it need but my patty formed really nicely. I did have a little problem with stickiness, but if I sprinkled a little bread crumbs on the patty before forming, there was no problems. Also, I couldn't get them to stop sticking to the foil on the grill, so I ended up pan frying them with a little bit of veggie oil and it gave them a nice little crust on the outside. I will definitely be making these again for our next barbeque.

text:
This is a great recipe. I made black bean tacos last night and had a large bowl left of the beans. I would have given this recipe 5 stars but couldn't since I didn't follow it to a T.

My left over beens had corn and roasted red peppers, cilantro and cayenne pepper in them. I didn't have any green bell peppers but I did have the roasted reds. I also used  a sweet chiptole mustard as the condiment

Overall, a GREAT recipe. I won't buy frozen burgers anymore knowing how easy they are.

One thing i would caution is that these are very HEARTY. I made them the same size as I make regular burgers and they were too big. I would say this recipe would make 6 filling patties.

text:
Well, the only other black bean burgers Ive tasted was the ones we can buy at Costco and I love those.  These did not taste anything like those but they had there own flavor and were so yummy.  My family thought they were too spicy and I didnt even put in 1/2 tsp of hot sauce in it.  I thought it was great and maybe needed more hot sauce. I did add a little salt to these after tasting the first burger.  These were easy to put together but were kind of sloppy when trying to form patties.  I had to throw tin foil down on my grill and just spoon the mixture on and form it with the spoon.  They cooked up just fine and hardened quickly so i could flip them.  In the end they looked just like a patty and held together well.   So end product was awsome but forming patties was quite difficult.

text:
These were so good.  They leave you very full.
I did as few of the posters suggested.  I dried the beans and got the excess water out of the onions, garlic, and peppers.  Instead of the 1/2 cup of breadcrumbs I used 3/4 cup.  I also used increased the egg by half.  They were the perfect consistency for patties.  I think next time I may add a little spice with crushed red pepper or a jalapeno pepper.  These are VERY comparable to the store bought frozen patties.  You will not be disappointed.

These were great! Though I made quite a few changes just because of personal preference. I ended up using quite a bit more than 1/2 a cup of breadcrumbs. I didn't have any problems with getting them to form up, but that may have been because of the freezing or the use of extra bread crumbs.  They tasted amazing! Confirmed by vegetarian and non vegetarians alike. Will definitely make again.

Very tasty.This is the second time using the recipe and I loved them better the second time. I pretty much followed the recipe but I drained my beans and let them sit after mashing them so the beans   dried out a bit not a bad thing (Accident - ran to the store but adding a little water did the trick). I chopped my vegetables and sauteed them, I also added more bread crumbs until the mixture held together well and I placed them in the pan to cook. Adding more breadcrumbs made them better this time as they were really sticky last time, egg was undone, also flattened them out more. I got 4 patties. Added a slice of mozzarella cheese and the fixings...Yum!

text:
Let me qualify this review by first saying that I LOVE real, beef hamburgers.  hopefully that will explain why i sound so harsh.    i was driven to this recipe by the cheapness of black beans and am trying to find a way to eat them that doesn't taste like eating cardboard.  lentils and chickpeas i can do... but beans sort of elude me.    For me the word 'burger' has a powerful association with delicious, warm beef juices dripping down your chin, and also a sense of pleasure from the post-consumption mini-coma.  it isnt really fair to ask any sort of burger 'replacement' to compete with that.  i tried calling them 'patties' or something else w/o the associative power of the word 'burger', but i fear it was too late.    on a more rational note- i followed all the suggestions about how to make them stay together to no avail.  of the 9 i made, i did not have 1 come out as a solid patty.  I had more bean 'crumbles'.   I also found them all to be quite dry bland (my kingdom for some beef juices!), and had to add lots of pico de gallo and hot sauce to get them down the gullet.  my roommate was less condemning.  so if you are into the super-healthy thing and aren't bothered by blandness... this may not be so bad.  if you are a burger lover, this will be disappointing.

text:
Definitely no more frozen black bean burgers.  This was cheaper and most important, just as tasty.  I followed some of the advice and used two eggs and a full cup of bread crumbs.  I also mashed the beans in a food processor instead of with a fork (was already using it so I figured why not make it easier on myself).  I baked instead of grilled.  The only issue was that the larger burgers didn't stay together as well as the smaller ones I made (bite-sized for my toddler), but that didn't really bother me.  Good spice.  I don't usually add too much salt to my dishes anyway.  I may use ground flax seed the next time.  It's been a great binder in other recipes I've used it in.  I would definitely recommend this recipe to others.  Thank you.  :)

This was amazing. I loved it, and it's very WW friendly.  I followed other reviewers suggestions and rinsed the beans and pat them dry, and got rid of the excess water in the veggies, as well as increasing the bread crumbs slightly. They stuck together, and I used a hamburger patty press to make them pretty :)  These are AMAZING. No joke, I'm not one of those people who review everything as delicious, and I am quite picky. These will be a staple for me.

text:
I will NEVER buy frozen veggie burgers ever again.  I did put in the freezer about 1 hour prior to baking.  Only changes were 1 tsp ground cumin, 1 shredded carrot and 1 shredded jalapeno pepper instead of the hot sauce.  Also used 10 crushed fat free saltine crackers for the bread crumbs and 1/4 cup egg beaters for the real egg.  It made 4 really decent sized burgers.  Almost a fat free food and will make on a regular basis.  The only item I had to buy was a can of black beans.  I had everything else already on hand.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very simple, very good, and very easy to modify.  I can honestly say this is my new favorite bean burger.  I started making these and then realized I was out of bread crumbs so I used matzo meal as a substitute.  I was a little nervous about the amount of spicy seasoning but didn't notice it in the burger once cooked.  I followed the advice of other reviewers and used two eggs.  I also do not have a food processor, so I diced my ingredients finely and mashed the beans with a potato masher.  My mixture was very sticky but it cooked perfectly.  I also made mine on the stovetop over medium heat.  I lightly sprayed a pan, covered, and flipped halfway when it was nice and brown.  It took about 10 minutes.

text:
I too had to add more bread crumbs than the recipe called for, and even then I was worried because the mixture seemed rather gloopy, but they actually turned out pretty good! This is my first time making veggie burgers, so I wasn't really sure what to expect. Once I got past the expectation that it should actually resemble hamburger meat in any way, I appreciated that they tasted good! Something in the flavor makes me want to try version with Mexican flavors, cheese, sour cream and/or salsa. I tried this recipe mostly as a way of trying to get more fiber into my diet. A black bean patty on a whole wheat bun is about 40% of my fiber needs in one meal! Much tastier than fiber drinks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always have a hard time getting these not to stick no matter how much spray or oil I use...but I LOVE the flavor & my meat eater boyfriends over the years have too!
Update: I have made these so many times...what I do now is make the mix ahead of time & let them sit in the fridge as patties for about an hour or 2..I heat some veg oil-about an inch (Olive oil has never worked for me, it always soaks into the patties & makes them weird) I fry these up (2-3 mins each side) carefully turning them. I figure they're healthy enough I can afford to fry them in a little oil to have a burger that will hold together & the little bit of crunch on the outside is an added bonus!

So good and so easy. Never tried grilling them, but baking them is so quick and simple. Feel free to use bread crumbs or a combo of bread crumbs and oats. I will say that it is a thick burger and needs lots of good toppings like tomato, lettuce, grilled onion etc. Whole family liked them!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7059540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to give this 4 stars just because I made a few changes. But this is a great base recipe, and I really think it would be delicious as written! In case you want to know here is what I did: chopped the veggies (peppers, jalapeno, onion, garlic) in the food processor and sauteed them; used a mix of bread crumbs and oatmeal; seasoned to taste and not by tsp or tbsp; and added Worcestershire and liquid smoke. I did not add extra breadcrumbs or egg. The mixture was fine. If you grill, watch the time. We had to grill for a little longer than written. But this made a fantastic veggie burger. We won't ever buy store brands again. Thank you so much for the wonderful ideas!!

text:
These are great!  The texture was really moist for me, and not really like a burger (I'm not a vegetarian) but still yummy!  I just had a can of black beans in the pantry and wanted to do something with them and found this recipe.  I baked them for the recommended time, and they look like they are getting dried out, but they were crisp on the outside and moist on the inside.  I subbed Worcestershire sauce for the chili sauce and only used a tsp. of the seasonings.  Also added salt and pepper and they were great!  I also did my beans in the food processor as well.  Much easier than mashing them with a fork!

I don't cook often, but I'm getting sick of packaged veggie burgers so I decided to give these a try. Boy am I glad I did! Delicious! I used two eggs as suggested, red/orange pepper because I prefer them, and Japanese bread crumbs because that's all I had (3 cups). Otherwise I followed the recipe as-written and these turned out great! I didn't have any problems with them falling apart, the flavor was awesome, and they look really nice too. My guest who makes her own black bean burgers gave them an A+ as well. The only change I might make next time is to add a pinch of salt. This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
These are delish! I will however, do things a little differently the next time I make them. A quick pulse or two is all you'll need in the food processor. I went a little too long and has onions & peppers that were practically pureed. I had to squeeze the extra water out of them and it got pretty messy. The flavor was great, I think adding some corn would take it over the top! Be sure to freeze right after making them so they hold their shape, they tend to fall apart while cooking so it's easier to cook them frozen. Definitely a keeper!

text:
Most delicious veggie burger I have ever tried!I made mine from dried beans. I added 1/2 cup of corn,and brown rice in place of the bread crumbs. I also used 1 TBSP flaxseed meal mixed with 3 TBSP boiling water as an egg substitute. All these variations are for people like me who have allergies to eggs & wheat. I removed the liquid from the veggies and corn before mixing with beans but still had a hard time holding the burger together. But the taste is so fantastic that I really dont mind it falling apart. Better than real beef burgers. Oh ya- I also added Chipotle sauce to mine to make it superb!!!!!

text:
These ruled!  The only changes I made were that I added double the breadcrumbs (didn't want it to be like refried beans), I added pepperjack cheese (best decision ever) and dipped in chipotle mayo (just blended together a bit of mayo and a canned chipotle pepper). Oh, also I did use 2 eggs instead of one. I made sure to strain the onions and peppers as recommended.  These tasted amazing.  I loved them as did my boyfriend who had never had any sort of vegetarian burger.  These are FAR better than the burgers you can buy at a restaurant or in the grocery store.

text:
Good as written, but needs some tweaking to make Great.  I will probably try again and use some of the other reviewers' suggestions to try to bump this up another star or two.  I love that it's simple, homemade, vegetarian, preservative free, soy free, etc.  However, my biggest complaint is the texture - just crumbly if made as written.  I suppose the type of bread you use could have some bearing there - not sure - I used Dave's Killer Bread "Goodseed" which is nice and moist.  I did reduce the chili sauce to 1 teaspoon for my spice-wimpy tongue, and the cumin to 1 t. as I find cumin delicious but often too strong.  Thanks for a good start - I will likely try this one again, with some small changes, until I get it just the wait I like it.

userID:
1436799
Display Name:
WYNDERLON
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
123
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the most delicious bean burger recipe I've made. I thought making less lumpy burgers would help keep them together so I threw the bell pepper (I used red instead of green), onion, and garlic in a food processor and processed until it was the consistency of mashed potato. I added this to the mashed black beans, I then added canned corn and peas. I realized I was out of chili powder so I used 1/2 tbs paprika. I used Panko bread crumbs, adding 1/4 cup to the amount, and made sure to spray the cooking sheet with canola oil. I noticed the medium sized bean patties stayed together the best. Definitely a keeper! :)

These were awesome!  I didn't have any of the reported problems other reviewers had...my recipe yielded four good sized patties.  I was afraid the Thai chili sauce would lose it's kick, but it stayed with the burgers :)  I also added some dried cilantro for a little extra flavor.  I paired them up with the Arnold Multi-grain Sandwich Thins and some of the creole mayo on this site.  I will definitely make these again since they make such a healthy and filling lunch!

Yummy! A good recipe to modify to suit your own tastes. I omitted the garlic, green pepper and hot sauce and just used 1 onion and some corn. I was afraid of them being too bland so I added 1/4 tsp of salt. Instead of using boxed breadcrumbs, I put two slices of toasted bread in the blender and made my own. I also doubled the recipe and got 11 good-sized burgers out of it. Everyone loved these. I will not be buying many frozen ones from now on!!

text:
These are always superb.  I follow the recipe verbatim and they turn out perfect.  I found that the best method to preparing these is to bake them (for about 30mins as well); I've made them by frying in a pan, and throwing them on my George Foreman grill (I don't have a regular grill), both are which still good, but I like the baked version better.  And yes, make sure to squeeze the onions/pepper/garlic mixture in a mesh strainer and blot with paper towels to rid excess water, the mixture turns out nicer and holds together better.  A definite fav.

This was great recipe, I did not use the Thai chili/hot sauce since my  husband can't take food that's too hot.  So, I followed the ingredients exactly as the recipe and instead of baking it/grilling it I very very lightly fried it in x-tra virgin olive oil, very lightly only to coat it.    TIP: It is not salty so if you like more salt than just a hint of taste, either use a bit of salt or use feta cheese when you assemble your burger.

Thanks for sharing this GREAT recipe. I am now a hit with the veggie and health food crowd when I grill.

Maria Gismondi

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7669027.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok, let me preface by saying that I doubled the recipe and then also used twice as many eggs and about twice as much breadcrumbs as well and this recipe made 8 GIGANTIC burgers. They were too big for the buns! I also used poblano peppers instead of green for a little extra kick. I'm giving these 3 stars because they were just "eh" to me. I feel like they definitely needed more spices, though I'm not exactly sure what. I also made them for the purpose of grilling on our Weber, but they were waaaaay too soft to flip without ruining, so we ended up doing them in a pan on the stove. I suppose if you wanted to you could always start them there and then transfer them once the egg firmed them up a bit.  They smelled delicious while mixing them, so I was sure they were going to blow everyone away (and the ratings led me to believe this as well), but honestly they fell a bit short of my expectations. They were also time consuming because I made my black beans from scratch, but I don't know that the payoff was worth it. I think next time I'll used canned beans and try using more veggies and twice the spices in the mix...   UPDATE: I had these again for dinner, and for some reason they were much tastier than I remembered this time. ??? I had frozen them and just did them in a skillet--didn't add anything--but I had to edit and give these another star. :) Still think they need to be spicier, but I whipped up some chipotle mayo which was fab with them.

text:
I kept the ingredients the same, but changed up the method a little. I pureed the beans in the blender (MagicBullet, actually) with the eggs and finely chopped the onion and green pepper, and used garlic powder instead of fresh (about 1/2 teaspoon). I baked them in the oven as directed. My family -- including three picky kids and a picky husband -- LOVED them! My husband, who is a self-proclaimed veggie-burger-hater said they were better than beef. In fact, he heated up a leftover one tonight after having a "REAL" beef burger and said that the black bean burger was better BY FAR!!! I will absolutely use this recipe again and again! THANK YOU!!!

These are fantastic. Never made any type of black bean burger before and I am in love. They held together perfect, I took the advice of another reviewer and dried the beans, and strained the liquid from the onion/green pepper mixture best I could. I didn't have to freeze them. My only substitution/change was 3/4 tsp garlic powder in stead of fresh garlic. ps - and they really are superb with ancho chipotle ranch! (I used T. Marzetti's low fat version found in the produce section) Enjoy!

text:
I made these last night and think the recipe is a good base, but needs some additions.  I added jalapeno, cilantro and a little tofu to my mixture.  Even with the jalapeno, hot sauce and chili powder, the burger was still bland and not spicy.  I think it needs some salt and pepper because I can only taste dry beans and cumin.  I used a cilantro sauce on my bun instead of ketchup or mustard and that seemed to add some much needed flavor.  One of the reviews suggested quinoa and I think that would be a great idea.  Not a bad recipe, but you'll want to tweak it to your taste.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fun and easy. I cut back on the spices and topped it with pepperjack cheese and a heaping spoon-full of salsa instead. It was good- gave me a little bit of a stomach ache, but I attribute that to "too many" beans all at once. Still- liked it a lot. I think if it hadn't been for the cheese and salsa it would have been pretty dry. Other minor notes: I used matzo meal instead of breadcrumbs b/c its what I had. Works just as well. I don't have a food processor but a good fine chopping was all mine needed- it held together just fine. I think the key to that is (as other reviewers have said) removing moisture from the beans. I did that by pressing the lid of the can down as hard as I could to let the juices come out before spooning them into the bowl for mashing. (if you do this make sure you washed the can beforehand).

I used thawed green peppers from the freezer and egg substitute in place of the egg. The only bummer was that a couple fell apart when I went to flip them.  Ate them with a little ketchup and some extra hot sauce. Will make again.

userID:
3293117
Display Name:
andy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmm! These are good! I made these for Father's Day (although veggie burgers aren't exactly a guy burger, come to think of it) and they turned out delicious. My mum especially liked them. Cut the amount of chili powder to 2/3 tbsp, but the amount of hot sauce was perfect. Also, if you've forgotten to strain the green pepper/onions like I did, you can add breadcrumbs (or crushed crackers of any sort) up to 1 1/4 cup instead of the 1/2 cup specified. Make sure you add enough so that the patty is able to hold its shape when rolled into a ball or flattened in the palm. Will definitely be making these again for a girls' night. Thanks!

These burgers are much better than anything you can find in the frozen food section and in most restaurants.

text:
I was very unimpressed with these burgers. My main complaint is that they are just too mushy. I made the patties in the morning, froze them, then let them thaw for 4hrs or so in the fridge before I cooked them for dinner. Due to their consistency, I would definitely recommend baking them because that limits contact with the fragile patties. Nevertheless, they were still too mushy. Also, I would suggest roasting the garlic. The raw and bitter flavor of the garlic is quite noticeable since the burgers are essentially heated up, not cooked. I would like to attribute the poignant and unpleasant 'zest' of the burgers to the raw garlic, but without repeating it could have something to do with the spice combo as well.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good! My secret is chipotle peppers (for smoky flavor and heat) and cooking them on a panini press. I doubled the recipe exactly (using red bell pepper) rinsing and drying as suggested, and added 2 fresh jalapenos and about 5 chipotle in adobo to the food processor. I also used 1 extra egg (3 in total), 1/2 cup cooked quinoa (or rice), salt, and 2/3 cup thawed corn. I cooked them on my Cuisinart Griddler (George Foreman-type grill thing), which pressed them together and browned them nicely. It made 12 spicy burgers which I will freeze. So nice not to drop so much cash on Morningstar Farms!

city:

country:
None
text:
These were fun to make, not too laborious, flexible in terms of ingredient swops, cheap, and also particularly great for vegetarians that are mindful of protein intake (considering the beans, egg (up-ed it to 2 as someone recommended) and sliced cheese which is yummy melted atop the patties).  I also rinsed the beans and let them drain overnight to dry out - saves that extra drying step, plus paper towels.  To be fair, I didn't have the same spices on hand so I made some changes - substituted crushed red peppers for the chili powder and added some curry powder and onion salt as well - it still all came out well.  I also used Panko for the bread crumbs, which worked fine.  My veggie bf really liked these burgers, so we decided our next weekend activity will be mass-producing a stash of these for the freezer for future quick-and-nutritious dinners.  Thanks for uploading!

I have a small cafe and these babies are going on my menu! They freeze and reheat well. I did add some Chipotle salsa, and followed some suggestions to increase the egg to 2 and subbed oats for the bread crumbs. Microwaved to reheat, served on wholewheat flatbread with ranch dressing, red onion, lettuce and tomato. My customers are raving over them!

I thought that these burgers were truly delicious!  I've been a vegetarian for a little over a year now and have been trying to find new recipes all of the time. userID:

Display Name:
Cheri Sundaram
isPro:

followersCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7152805.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good...but they crumbled.  I used 1/2c oats and kidney beans instead of black b/c that's all I had.  I rinsed and dried the beans and put the pepper/onion mix in some cheese cloth and squeezed the excess water out.  I put the patties in the freezer to firm up.  I started out baking them but they started to crumble when I tried to flip them after 10 min so I moved them to a fry pan with some olive oil.  That didn't help they still crumbled.  So what I did was crumble up the rest of it and put slices of cheese over the mixture and cover until the cheese melted.  The melted cheese held the crumbles together so I was able to transfer something resembling a buger onto the bun.  What we didn't eat on a bun, we put on top of some tortilla chips and cheese, it was fantastic.  I will try this recipe again with black beans and an extra egg for a burger, but I'll probably even make it again as a topping for nachos.  The crumbly bean mixture was an excellent topping.

Absolutely the best! No more packaged frozen veggie burgers ever! I substituted a few things. I followed the advice of another reviewer and used two eggs instead of one. I also used rolled oats instead of bread crumbs. I put the onion and pepper in my food processor, and then added the beans. I drained the chopped onion and pepper to make the mixture less watery. Mine didn't fall apart at all. Cooked on my electric griddle about 10 minutes per side. I won't be buying frozen black bean burgers at the store any more-- these are super easy and taste great!

As far as the seasoning and veggies involved goes, this recipe is GREAT.  I used red and yellow bell peppers and added some fresh cilantro I had lying around, and these taste delicious.  THE PROBLEM WAS that they were way too dry.  Next time I'm going to try leaving out the egg (in order for them to be vegetarian and vegan) and I'm going to add some olive oil and ketchup to moisten these things up. I made a double batch and froze mine (individually wrapped) and that worked out great.  I can through a frozen one on my GOFO grill and it still tastes super fresh.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these burgers for a Christmas party so my sister would have a vegetarian option. She loved them and, shocker of all shockers, so did my husband and daughter (they don't even LIKE black beans!). I followed other users' suggestions about doubling the eggs in the recipe and had no issues with the burgers falling apart. I also used half the amount of chili powder and tobasco sauce. When I did a 'test burger' right after mixing things up, I wasn't sure if it would be hot enough but after the uncooked patties sat overnight in the fridge they had plenty of heat and I was glad I didn't add in the rest of the spice. Fried them up on a non-stick griddle and they were fabulous! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This is one of my favorite recipes - so easy, delicious, and healthy.  I am allergic to the additives in store-bought veggie burgers and this is a great alternative.  Even my meat-loving husband likes them.  I do add extra bread crumbs, about two slices of toasted bread processed in the food processor.  Drying the beans and the vegetables does help everything stay together, as well.  I process everything - the bread, vegetables, and beans and my food processor, which gives the burgers the best texture and makes the recipe so quick and easy.  Try it, you will love it!

None
text:
Tried these tonight they were great.Did as other suggested and drain garlic,onion and pepper.wash and drained beans and patted excess water off.mashed beans with potato masher and add other ingredients.used 1/2 tsp. cumin and 3 or 4 dashes of tabassco sause in place of chili sause.add 3/4cup bread crumbs last .and let set a few min. to absorb any extra moisture.sprayed non stick pan with pam a fried on low 5 to 7 mins on each side made 5 nice burgers.

Ummm...good! This recipe was delicious! Thanks everybody for your suggestions on how to keep them from being too runny and sticking. I did the drain, rinse and pat dry method. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My Hubby's favorite! Great texture and flavor, in need of no adjustments. To deal with the stickiness of the mixture, simply spray a 1/2 cup measure with non-stick spray, spoon the mixture in, and slide it out onto your cooking surface. You can spray the bottom of the cup and use it to flatten the mound to a burger shape. I ended up frying them because it was too hot in my kitchen to use the oven. Fry for about 5-7 min. per side, on medium heat. These will become a household regular for us!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So delicious, but it needed some modifications to make it perfect.  I add all ingredients (+ an extra 1/2 cup of bread crumbs) to the food processor, and grind it until it's like a paste.  Then I add two fresh tomatoes and pulse until those are chunky.  Then I add a bit of oil to the george foreman grill and cook them on there, one at a time.  I took the advice of another reviewer and make an avocado ranch sauce (using non-fat yogurt), and put a little of that on each, served on whole wheat rolls.
There really is no comparison to the frozen kind, these are SO delicious!

text:
This is a very good basic/starter recipe for making your own black bean burgers.  The only thing I did a little diff is add some salt, make patties smaller (got 7 out of the batch), threw beans in processor instead of hand mashing, added extra bread crumbs so they would form up better, and I pan cooked them with a little olive oil.  They came out very nice.  Next time I make a black bean burger I intend to add some basmati rice, and maybe use some oats like a prev. reviewer recommends.

text:
Good recipe.  I didn't change the ingredients, but did change the methods.  I minced the veggies and food-processed (lightly) the beans.  Next time I will cut down on the cumin, however.  At 1T, each pattie has nearly 1t, which didn't agree with my tummy or taste buds.  My patties did break apart when I turned them over, but I made them very thin.  So, I will play with that.
